Notes: Victoria:  The Workplace Directions (No 23) come into force at 6:00pm on 26 March 2021 and replace the Workplace Directions (No 22).  “In any shared spaces (such as lunchrooms) and publicly accessible areas at the Work Premises (except in relation to any shared spaces in schools, nonschool senior secondary providers, childcare or early childhood services, or higher education services used by students or children, including classrooms, and clinical areas of a hospital), an employer must comply with the density quotient for each shared space and each publicly accessible area”    The density quotient is one person for every 2 square meters.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210326103418/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2023%29%20-%2026%20March%202021.pdf

On Monday 29th march 2021 a joint media statement by the QLD Premier and Minister for Trade Annastacia Palaszczuk and the QLD Minister for Health and Ambulance Services Yvette D'Ath announced that ""The Greater Brisbane region has now entered a three-day lockdown and increased restrictions are in place across Queensland as evidence of community transmission of the UK strain of COVID-19 continues to emerge.""  Further that ""From 5pm Monday 29 March to 5pm Thursday 1 April 2021, people in Greater Brisbane (Brisbane City Council, Logan City Council, Moreton Bay Regional Council, Ipswich City Council and Redland City Council) will be required to stay at home except for essential reasons. The restrictions will be reviewed on Wednesday night.""    ""Schools will close until next term, except for the children of essential workers and vulnerable children. Childcare centres will remain open. ""    The Restrictions for Queensland direction which was enacted at 5pm Monday 29th March, direct that individuals may leave their homes to attend university but only to the extend to which it is not possible to undertake learning remotely.   Universities located in Brisbane closed all on campus activities.  Archived links to official communications around campus closings provided for Queensland University of Technology and the University of Queensland.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404012130/https://about.uq.edu.au/covid-19-student-communication  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404012103/https://www.qut.edu.au/additional/coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404010601/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-03-30/brisbane-lockdown-rules-mask-essential-shopping-school-gathering/100037408     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404011313/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-impacted-areas-3     https://web.archive.org/web/20210331051600/https://statements.qld.gov.au/statements/91825

Queensland: A joint statement by the Premier and Minister for Trade Annastacia Palaszczuk and Minister for Health and Ambulance Services Yvette D'Ath published Thursday, 01 April, 2021 at 01:26 PM states that ""Greater Brisbane’s lockdown ended at 12 noon today....Importantly, a number of restrictions will be put in place for all Queenslanders to protect against further transmission of COVID-19 for the next two weeks.""    Schools will not return as previously scheduled school holidays commence Friday 2nd April and will return for the next school term on Monday 19 April.       Restrictions for Queensland (No. 2) is effective from Effective from: 12.00pm AEST 1 April 2021 and revokes the  previous Restrictions for Queensland Direction made on 29 March 2021. This direction stipulates that ""Universities and other higher educational institutions such as TAFEs and RTOs must comply with occupant density in large lecture settings.  Note – large lecture settings may operate for one person per 2 square metres or 100 per cent of seated venue capacity with ticketed and allocated seating in accordance with the definition of occupant density in Schedule 2.  The requirement to collect contact information only applies to large lecture settings operating for 100 per cent of seated venue capacity with ticketed and allocated seating.  Note – smaller education and teaching sessions, such as group seminars, tutorials, practicals and laboratory-based learnings, and vocational training sessions are not subject to occupant density. Physical distancing should be observed to the extent possible.  Businesses, activities and undertakings such as cafes or sporting-based activities conducted at universities or other educational institutions must comply with the applicable requirements under this Direction.""     Victoria: Victoria:  The Workplace Directions (No 23) came into force at 6:00pm on 26 March 2021 and replace the Workplace Directions (No 22).  They remain current as at 4th April 2021.   “In any shared spaces (such as lunchrooms) and publicly accessible areas at the Work Premises (except in relation to any shared spaces in schools, nonschool senior secondary providers, childcare or early childhood services, or higher education services used by students or children, including classrooms, and clinical areas of a hospital), an employer must comply with the density quotient for each shared space and each publicly accessible area”    The density quotient is one person for every 2 square meters.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404073238/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/victorias-restriction-levels-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404073211/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Workplace%20%28AIO%29%20Directions%20%28No%2020%29%20-%2026%20March%202021.pdf

The revoked direction previously stipulated that ""Universities and other higher educational institutions such as TAFEs and RTOs must comply with occupant density in large lecture settings.  Note – large lecture settings may operate for one person per 2 square metres or 100 per cent of seated venue capacity with ticketed and allocated seating in accordance with the definition of occupant density in Schedule 2. Note – smaller education and teaching sessions, such as group seminars, tutorials, practicals and laboratory-based learnings, and vocational training sessions are not subject to occupant density. Physical distancing should be observed to the extent possible.  Businesses, activities and undertakings such as cafes or sporting-based activities conducted at universities or other educational institutions must comply with the applicable requirements under this Direction.""     From the 15th April 2021 and up to date as of 19th April 2021 there appears to be no COVID-19 related policy restrictions applying to schools or universities in QLD.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210419104437/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/revocation-of-restrictions-for-queensland-no.-2  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419104947/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-for-queensland-2  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419105036/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/government-actions/roadmap-to-easing-queenslands-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419105153/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/movement-gathering-direction    Victoria:   In an easing of restrictions, The Workplace Directions (No 24) came into force at 11:59pm on 9 April 2021 and replace the Workplace Directions (No 23).  They remain current as at 19th April 2021.   “Office areas (including shared spaces that form part of an office area such as kitchens, lunchrooms and bathrooms) used only by staff that are not publicly accessible are [now] also not subject to the density quotient. However, the density quotient applies to any publicly accessible areas (including in relation to a school, non-school senior secondary providers, or childcare or early childhood service, or higher education service)”  Therefore except in limited circumstances where members of the public (ie not students or staff) are visiting a school in Victoria - density quotients no longer apply.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210419110159/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202104/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2024%29%20-%209%20April%202021.pdf     New South Wales:   The NSW Public Health (COVID-19 Gathering Restrictions) Order 2021 commenced at the beginning of 29 March 2021 and remains current as of the 19th April 2021.  It outlines current gathering restrictions for NSW which, for non-residential premises (with some exceptions are) “(a) the number of persons that is equivalent to 1 person per 2 square metres of space in the premises, or (b) 25 persons.”  However, the order further states that “Gathering at a school, university or other educational institution or child care facility that is necessary for the normal business of the school, university, institution or facility but does not include a school event that involves members of the community in addition to staff and students”  Except in limited circumstances where members of the public (ie not students or staff) are visiting a school, there are no COVID-19 related policies in NSW that currently impact the normal functions of schools or universities.   web.archive.org/web/20210419112216/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx   Unable to archive the URL to the full direction as the Way Back Machine repeatedly generated an “internal error”    Tasmania:   According to the Tasmanian government COVID-19 website and up to date as of the 19th April 2021 Schools, universities, education institutions, childcare facilities, child and family centres are exempt from current COVID-19 gathering restrictions.   There are no COVID-19 related policies in Tasmania that currently impact the normal functions of schools or universities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419111737/https://www.coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/gatherings-density-and-physical-distancing     Northern Territory  The Northern Territory COVID-19 Directions (No. 56) 2020: Safety Measures for Places, Businesses, Activities, Services and Premises directs that A school, university or other educational institution (among others) require a COVID-19 safety plan, COVID-19 safety supervisor, COVID-19 safety measures and contact information required.    This means that hand sanitiser or other handwashing facilities must be provided; signage must be displayed to promote COVID safe practices; contact details from members of the public who visit for must be collected; must submit a COVID safety plan every 6 mnths, and must have a nominated COVID-19 safety supervisor.   There are no COVID-19 related policies in The Northern Territory that appear to currently significantly impact the normal functions of schools or universities.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419113917/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0012/951879/cho-directions-no56-safety-measures-places-businesses-activities-services-premises.pdf     Western Australia   The Western Australian GATHERINGS AND ACTIVITIES DIRECTIONS (NO 2) came into effect at 12.01 am on 10 April 2021 and remain current as of 19th April 2021.  This direction provides that gatherings “at a school, university, educational institution or childcare facility that is necessary for the normal business of the facility;” are exempt from the restrictions outlined in the direction.   There are no COVID-19 related policies in Western Australia that appear to currently significantly impact the normal functions of schools or universities.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419114440/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/090421-Gathering-and-Activities-Directions-No2.pdf     Australian Capital Territory  Public Health (Restricted Activities –Gatherings, Business or Undertakings) Emergency Direction 2021 (No.3) came into effect at 9:00am on 14April2021 and remain current as of 19th April 2021.  This direction provides that gatherings “at a school, university, educational institution or childcare facility that is necessary for the normal business of the facility;” are exempt from the restrictions outlined in the direction.    There are no COVID-19 related policies in the Australian Capital Territory that appear to currently significantly impact the normal functions of schools or universities.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419114551/https://www.legislation.act.gov.au/ni/2021-216/     South Australia  The Emergency Management (Public Activities No 23) (COVID-19) Direction 2021 came into effect at 12:46 pm on 14 April 2021 and revokes the Emergency Management (Public Activities No 22) (COVID-19) Direction 2021.  It remains current as of 19 April 2021.   This direction provides that gatherings “a gathering at a school, university or other educational institution or a childcare facility, or in a vehicle used for the purposes of any such institution or facility, that is necessary for the normal business of the institution or facility;” are exempt from the restrictions outlined in the direction.    There are no COVID-19 related policies in South Australia that appear to currently significantly impact the normal functions of schools or universities.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419115425/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0005/374675/Public-Activities-No-23-14-04-2021.pdf

New South Wales:  The most recent amendments to The Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 commenced on 23 March 2021.   ""The object of this Order is to amend the Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 to clarify the maximum number of persons allowed on premises when the premises is being used as a nightclub and when the premises is being used for other purposes"".      However, the direction maintains that ""The Minister directs that premises in Greater Sydney must not be used as a nightclub.""    The NSW Government COVID19 website states that: ""In Greater Sydney, premises cannot operate as a nightclub (open late into the evening primarily for the purpose of providing a venue for patrons to dance), but may open to provide other services as long as the appropriate COVID-19 Safety Plan is in place, where relevant.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326104344/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx   Unable to archive the link to the legislative direction - repeatedly returning an error message.     Maintained a 2 Code - due to the required closing of night clubs in within Greater Sydney, Central Coast, and Wollongong.

Queensland: On Monday 29th march 2021 a joint media statement by the QLD Premier and Minister for Trade Annastacia Palaszczuk and the QLD Minister for Health and Ambulance Services Yvette D'Ath announced that ""The Greater Brisbane region has now entered a three-day lockdown and increased restrictions are in place across Queensland as evidence of community transmission of the UK strain of COVID-19 continues to emerge.""    Schedule 3 of the The Restrictions for Queensland direction was enacted at 5pm Monday 29th March and defines Non-essential business, activity, undertaking, premises or place and the restrictions placed on them.  Trading for some non-essential businesses has not entirely ceased but only allowed subject to very significant restrictions. For example Other religious and civil ceremonies, places of worship (excluding wedding ceremonies and funerals). Live streaming of a service may be conducted with the person conducting the service and a camera operator.   Therefore coded as a 3 targeted to the Greater Brisbane area.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210331051600/https://statements.qld.gov.au/statements/91825      https://web.archive.org/web/20210404010601/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-03-30/brisbane-lockdown-rules-mask-essential-shopping-school-gathering/100037408     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404011313/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-impacted-areas-3       New South Wales: The Public Health (COVID-19 Gathering Restrictions) Order 2021 commenced on 29 March 2021 and contains directions on gatherings, and the number of persons allowed on non-residential and residential premise.  This direction was a relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions for NSW.  In part, it now allows for nightclubs to operate. There are no restrictions on dancing, including at weddings and in pubs and nightclubs.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210404064140/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329012105/https://gazette.legislation.nsw.gov.au/so/download.w3p?id=Gazette_2021_2021-127.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404064320/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/what-you-can-do-nsw

Restrictions for Queensland (No. 2) direction is effective from Effective from: 12.00pm AEST 1 April 2021 and revokes the  previous Restrictions for Queensland Direction made on 29 March 2021.   This direction stipulates mandatory density limits ( one person per either 2 or 4 square meters) and mandatory collection of contract tracing information for a large range of workplaces including: Food and drink; Entertainment venues (including night clubs); Retail; Beauty and personal care services; Leisure and recreation; Residential facilities; Outdoor recreation; Non-residential institutions; Professional and elite sport; Adult entertainment venues and the sex industry. Queensland:   In a loosening of restrictions The Restrictions for Queensland Direction (No. 2) was revoked from 6:00am on 15 April 2021.   Restrictions on Businesses, Activities and Undertakings Direction (No. 18) are effective from 6am AEST 15 April 2021.  With exceptions this directions provides for a general density quotient for Queensland workplaces of 1 person per 2 square meters.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419104947/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-for-queensland-2   http://web.archive.org/web/20210419123343/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/business-activity-undertaking-direction    Victoria:   In a modest loosening of restrictions the Workplace Directions (No 24) commenced at 11:59:00pm on 9 April 2021.    With limited exceptions, these directions set a general requirement that workplaces must adhere to a density quotient of 1 person per 2 square meters.  Workplace (Additional Industry Obligations) Directions (No 21) commence at 11:59:00pm on 9 April 2021.  These directions provide more stringent restrictions for the following specific:   (a) poultry processing facilities; and  (b) abattoirs and meat processing facilities; and  (c) seafood processing facilities; and  (d) supermarket Work Premises and perishable food Work Premises;  and  (e) warehousing and distribution centres; and  (f) commercial cleaning services; and  (g) commercial passenger vehicle services; and  (h) horticulture operations using seasonal workers for seasonal  horticultural work; and  (i) care facilities; and  (j) ports of entry servicing international arrivals; and  (k) hotel quarantine; and  (l) hospitals; and  (m) Australian air transport operators.     An example of additional restrictions provided for by this direction are: ""(i) developing separate shifts in a way that minimises physical  interactions between groups of workers attending different shifts;  (ii) separates workers into work areas;  (iii) dividing work areas up further into separate teams;  (iv) providing separate break areas for the separate teams;   Workplace (Additional Industry Obligations) Directions (No 21) 5 of 19  (v) requiring teams to use separate entrances and exits from other  teams;  (vi) where workers are from the same household, ensuring they work  in the same shift and work area;  ""  Particularly due to these additional restrictions in place in Victoria, C2 coded as a T1.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210419122619/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202104/Workplace%20%28AIO%29%20Directions%20%28No%2021%29%20-%209%20April%202021.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419122032/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202104/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2024%29%20-%209%20April%202021.pdf

Victoria: The Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 18) came into force at 6:00pm on 26 March 2021 and replace the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 17). This new direction implements a relaxing of restrictions.    In Victoria, groups of up to 200 people can meet in a public outdoor space from any number of households.  An outdoor space is a park or garden in a public place outside of the home. It does not include private backyard.    The Restricted Activity Directions (Victoria) (No 11) come into force at 6:00pm 26 March 2021 and replace the Restricted Activity Directions (No 10).  This direction provides that, In Victoria  “Seated venues (indoor and outdoor) up to 75 per cent capacity of the total venue with a maximum of 1,000 patrons in each space. Density limits apply to non-seated areas.  Non seated venues (indoor) up to 75 per cent of capacity, with a maximum of 1000 patrons in each space. Density limits apply.  Non seated venues (outdoor) do not have patron caps but density limits apply  No cap on dance floors. Density limits apply, depending on the venue type.  Casinos to 75 per cent of venue capacity.  Removal of gaming machine caps.  All venues must use the Government QR Code Service, or API linked digital system, to maintain electronic record keeping.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326111234/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28No%2018%29%20-%2026%20March%202021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326111931if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-live  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326112159/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Restricted%20Activity%20Directions%20%28Victoria%29%20%28No%2011%29%20-%2026%20March%202021.pdf     New South Wales: The Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 directs that as of 26th march 2021.   In NSW No more than 50 people can gather outside in a public place which includes public parks, reserves, beaches, public gardens and spaces.   The maximum number of people that can attend a controlled outdoor event is subject to the one person per 2 square metre rule up to:  500 people if people are assigned to a seating area; or  2,000 people if the people are each assigned to a specific seat.  The event may be held in a public place that is enclosed by fencing or another form of barrier can be accessed only with a ticket. The gathering must not last longer than 5 hours. The organiser must have and comply with a COVID-19 Safety Plan, and electronic entry recording is compulsory.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210326112437/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/greater-sydney    Unable to archive the link to the full legal direction, repeatedly returned an error.

On Monday 29th march 2021 a joint media statement by the QLD Premier and Minister for Trade Annastacia Palaszczuk and the QLD Minister for Health and Ambulance Services Yvette D'Ath announced that ""The Greater Brisbane region has now entered a three-day lockdown and increased restrictions are in place across Queensland as evidence of community transmission of the UK strain of COVID-19 continues to emerge.""    Schedule 3 of the The Restrictions for Queensland direction was enacted at 5pm Monday 29th March and defines Non-essential business, activity, undertaking, premises or place and the restrictions placed on them. Entertainment venues including are closed without exception. This includes Casinos, gaming or gambling venues including wagering outlets that are open to, and accessible by, members of the public. Major Sports Stadiums. Concert venues, theatres, auditoriums and cinemas. Convention centres and show grounds. Indoor and outdoor events(Example – marathons, cultural festivals, fetes, expos). Theme parks, outdoor amusement parks, tourism experiences and arcades. Indoor play centres and unattended children’s rides and games in retail premises.             https://web.archive.org/web/20210331051600/https://statements.qld.gov.au/statements/91825      https://web.archive.org/web/20210404010601/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-03-30/brisbane-lockdown-rules-mask-essential-shopping-school-gathering/100037408     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404011313/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-impacted-areas-3

Queensland: A joint statement by the Premier and Minister for Trade Annastacia Palaszczuk and Minister for Health and Ambulance Services Yvette D'Ath published Thursday, 01 April, 2021 at 01:26 PM states that ""Greater Brisbane’s lockdown ended at 12 noon today....Importantly, a number of restrictions will be put in place for all Queenslanders to protect against further transmission of COVID-19 for the next two weeks.""      Restrictions for Queensland (No. 2) is effective from Effective from: 12.00pm AEST 1 April 2021 and revokes the  previous Restrictions for Queensland Direction made on 29 March 2021.  In part, this direction restricts public outdoor gatherings to a a maximum of 500 people.  Organised Indoor and outdoor events (Example – marathons, cultural festivals, fetes, expos) may operate with greater numbers of attendees.  However, COVID Safe Event Checklist or COVID Safe Event Plan and occupant density limitations apply.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210404070838/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/restrictions-for-queensland   https://web.archive.org/web/20210404071525/https://statements.qld.gov.au/statements/91833  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404075127/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/public-health-directions/restrictions-for-queensland

Queensland:   In a loosening of restrictions The Restrictions for Queensland Direction (No. 2) was revoked from 6:00am on 15 April 2021.   Restrictions on Businesses, Activities and Undertakings Direction (No. 18) are effective from 6am AEST 15 April 2021.    In part this Directions provides:   No limit for people gathering in outdoor public spaces across Queensland.  One person per 2m2 (e.g. restaurants, cafés, pubs, clubs, museums, art galleries, places of worship, convention centres and Parliament House), including standing, eating and drinking.  Indoor events: 500 people permitted at indoor events with a COVID Safe Event Checklist. Larger events require a COVID Safe Plan.  Ticketed venues: 100% capacity at allocated seated, ticketed venues with patrons encouraged to wear masks on entry and exit (e.g. theatre, live music, cinemas, indoor sports, universities and other higher education institutions). Performers can distance from audience at 2m, except choirs which remain at 4m from the audience.  Dancing: Dancing is allowed in all indoor and outdoor venues including pubs, beer gardens, clubs and nightclubs, subject to the one person per 2m2 rule.  Outdoor dance festivals and music festivals: Fewer than 500 people per day permitted without a COVID Safe Checklist, no requirement to collect contact details. Events with between 500 and 1499 people permitted with a COVID Safe Event Checklist. Larger events require a COVID Safe Event Plan.  Outdoor events: Anzac Day parades, fetes, fun runs and other outdoor only events do not need a COVID Safe Event Checklist or Event Plan.  Open air stadiums: 100% allocated seated and ticketed capacity (with a COVID Safe Plan). All patrons encouraged to wear masks on entry and exit.  Contact tracing information: All hospitality industry businesses (i.e. pubs, clubs, restaurants and cafés) in Queensland must comply with electronic contact information collection requirements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419104947/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-for-queensland-2   http://web.archive.org/web/20210419124003/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/government-actions/roadmap-to-easing-queenslands-restrictions      Victoria:   The Victorian Government COVID-19 Website states that ""From 11:59pm on Friday 9 April 2021, Victoria has further relaxed its COVIDSafe Settings. ""  Some of the changes that apply to public events are:  ""Seated areas at indoor and outdoor entertainment, cultural and sporting venues can use 100% of their seated capacity up to a maximum of 1,000 patrons per space. The density quotient still applies at these venues in non-seated spaces e.g. bathrooms and lobbies.  These venues include theatres,?cinemas,?music halls, concert halls,?auditoriums,?galleries,?museums, and sports and physical recreation facilities.  Non-seated?venues will continue to be required to apply a density quotient of 1 per 2sqm, except unstaffed gyms?(such as 24-hour gyms), which have a?four-square metre rule.  Non seated venues (outdoor) do not have patron caps but density limits apply.  Non-seated venues (indoor) are capped at 75% capacity and density limits apply.  No cap on dance floors, but density limits apply, depending on the venue type.  Casinos to 75 per cent of venue capacity.  All venues must use the Government QR Code Service, or API linked digital system, to maintain electronic record keeping. ""    In addition, the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 19) effective from 11:59:00pm on 9 April 2021 and current as of 19 April 2021, states in part that ""a person in the State of Victoria must not arrange  to meet, or organise or intentionally attend a gathering of, more than 199  other persons (with any infant under one year of age not counting towards  this limit) for a common purpose at a public place""    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419124827if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-live  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419125148/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-work    New South Wales:   In a loosening of restrictions The Public Health (COVID-19 Gathering Restrictions) Order 2021 was amended commencing 9 April 2021 and contains directions on gatherings, and the number of persons allowed on non-residential and residential premises.   In part, it states that ""Non-controlled outdoor public gatherings (up to 200): These events are restricted to 200 people (unless the gathering is a COVID-19 safe outdoor gathering with a COVID-19 Safety Plan.  COVID-19 safe outdoor gathering (up to 5,000): These events can have the lesser of 1 person per 2 square metres of space or 5,000 persons and do not need to be seated or enclosed by fencing and do not have a time limit. The organiser must have and comply with the relevant COVID-19 Safety Plan.  Controlled outdoor public gatherings (up to 10,000): A ticketed and seated COVID-19 safe outdoor gathering that does not last longer than 5 hours can have the maximum of the lesser of 1 person per 2 square metres of space or 10,000 persons. The event must be enclosed by fencing or another barrier. The organiser must have and comply with the relevant COVID-19 Safety Plan.""  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419125747/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx

Snap lockdown - ""People in the Perth and Peel regions will not be able to leave home for the next three days except for essential reasons, including work where it is not possible to work from home, shopping for essentials, and exercise with a maximum of four people for an hour.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210425131432/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/apr/23/perth-to-enter-snap-three-day-lockdown-after-covid-spreads-from-hotel-quarantine-into-community    http://web.archive.org/web/20210425132208/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown

Victoria and New South Wales continue to have the most stringent restrictions on social gatherings.     Victoria: The Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 18) came into force at 6:00pm on 26 March 2021 and replace the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 17).   This new direction implements a relaxing of restrictions.  Victorians can have up to 100 visitors to their home per day (intimate partners are not included in this cap). There is no limit on the number of households those visitors come from.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210326111234/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202103/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28No%2018%29%20-%2026%20March%202021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326111931if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-live    NSW: The Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on Gathering and Movement) Order 2021 directs that as of 26th march 2021.   Residents of NSW are allowed Up to 50 visitors from any number of households may visit another at any one time. Under the rules:  the total number of visitors includes adults and children  a member of the hosting household is not counted as a visitor  an overnight stay as part of a visit to someone’s house is allowed.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210326112437/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/greater-sydney   Unable to archive the link to the full legal direction, repeatedly returned an error.

On Monday 29th march 2021 a joint media statement by the QLD Premier and Minister for Trade Annastacia Palaszczuk and the QLD Minister for Health and Ambulance Services Yvette D'Ath announced that ""The Greater Brisbane region has now entered a three-day lockdown and increased restrictions are in place across Queensland as evidence of community transmission of the UK strain of COVID-19 continues to emerge.""  The Restrictions for Queensland direction was enacted at 5pm Monday 29th March and directs that no more that two visitors to a household per day are allowed. If leaving the home, individuals are allow to do so either with members of their own household and/or to meet one other person who is not a member of their household.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210331051600/https://statements.qld.gov.au/statements/91825      https://web.archive.org/web/20210404010601/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-03-30/brisbane-lockdown-rules-mask-essential-shopping-school-gathering/100037408     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404011313/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-impacted-areas-3

Each Australian State and Territory has some level of additional policies or recommendations for the use of public transport.   Below is the current policy/advise of each jurisdiction as on the 9th April 2021.     New South Wales:   The NSW government NSW transport website states that “From December 14 2020, COVID Safe capacity on trains has been lifted to 55 per cent, capacity on buses lifted to 45 percent, capacity on light rail lifted to 25 per cent and capacity on ferries lifted to 51 per cent.” In conversation with a NSW Transport representative on 10th April 2021 via the 131 500 information line, I was advised that this information remains up to date.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210328222751/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-what-you-can-do  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410021757/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-safer-travel-guidance     Victoria:   The Victorian Government Public Transport Victoria website states that face masks are compulsory on public transport in Victoria.  There is also a recommendation and financial incentive for commuters to travel outside peak hours.  “Travel outside peak times when there are less people on the network. On weekdays get a 30% off peak discount on metropolitan services or travel free before 7.15am on metropolitan trains.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410023015/https://www.ptv.vic.gov.au/more/coronavirus-covid-19/   Queensland:   The Queensland Government Public Transport website states encourages travellers to physically distance while travelling and to travel at of peak times.  The QLD Government have developed a ‘Service capacity tracker’ that allows commuters to see where there is enough space on their preferred service to maintain physical distancing.  Additional peak hour train and bus services, in response to COVID-19 continue.  Masks are currently mandatory on public transport through-out QLD.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210410024119/https://translink.com.au/updates/14696   https://web.archive.org/web/20210319052936/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/help-and-advice/public-transport  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401222648/https://translink.com.au/travel-with-us/covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210325183126/https://translink.com.au/travel-with-us/covid-19/capacity-tracker     Western Australia:   The WA Government Public Transport Authority Website states that “The PTA is closely monitoring what is happening with coronavirus (COVID-19) and is increasing the cleaning regime on all the vehicles in our Transperth, Transwa, TransRegional and School Bus Services road and rail fleets.”  No significant COVID-19 policies resulting in or significantly reduce volume/route/means of transport available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407044301/https://www.pta.wa.gov.au/     Tasmania:   The Tasmanian Government COVID-19 website states that “Passengers are encouraged to keep physical distancing in mind and choose a seat away from others where possible….anyone feeling unwell should avoid using public transport. For short trips, consider walking or cycling. Travel outside peak periods where possible. While waiting at bus stops, practice social distancing. Adults seeking to board a bus which has a high number of passengers are asked to consider waiting for the next service where available. This request does not apply to children.”  No significant COVID-19 policies resulting in or significantly reduce volume/route/means of transport available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403114036/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/transport     Northern Territory:   The Northern Territory government COVID-19 website states that “Public transport, including buses, taxis and rideshare services, continues to operate in the Northern Territory (NT). To minimise the risk of contracting or spreading coronavirus (COVID-19), passengers must practice good hygiene and physical distancing where possible.”  No significant COVID-19 policies resulting in or significantly reduce volume/route/means of transport available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410031847/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/public-transport       Australian Capital Territory:   The Australian Capital Territory Government Website site states that “Use of public transport during off peak times is encouraged where possible. This helps with physical distancing onboard and at stops and stations. Off peak travel is also cheaper…. Bus and light rail services continue to run to their regular schedule. Almost 700 more services have been introduced each weekday and more than 200 services each Saturday, to help you spread out your travel.”    You can check the quietest times to travel on light rail and Rapid bus services using the Transport Canberra online capacity tool..”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210410032002/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/community/transport   https://web.archive.org/web/20210410032112/https://www.transport.act.gov.au/getting-around/timetables/when-to-use-public-transport

Each Australian State and Territory has some level of additional policies or recommendations for the use of public transport.   Below is current policy/advice as on the 23rd April 2021 for some states.     New South Wales:   The NSW government NSW transport website COVID-19: Safer travel guidance states that “More than 1,200 extra weekly services will be added to the 3,300 extra services already running across the network to help customers stay COVID safe and enjoy all the city and surrounds has to offer. These extra services will help you continue to make smart travel choices. All extra services continue to run..”     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423032509/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-what-you-can-do  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423032624/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-safer-travel-guidance     Queensland:   The Queensland Government Public Transport website states that additional peak hour train and bus services, in response to COVID-19 continue.  Additional bus services have been extended until 25 June 2021, All additional train services introduced in will become permanent.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423032943/https://translink.com.au/updates/14696   web.archive.org/web/20210423033135/https://translink.com.au/travel-with-us/covid-19/pt-plan    Western Australia:   The WA Government Public Transport Authority Website states that “The PTA is closely monitoring what is happening with coronavirus (COVID-19) and is increasing the cleaning regime on all the vehicles in our Transperth, Transwa, TransRegional and School Bus Services road and rail fleets.”  No evidence of COVID-19 policies resulting in or significantly reduce volume/route/means of transport available.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423033346/https://www.pta.wa.gov.au/

On Monday 29th march 2021 a joint media statement by the QLD Premier and Minister for Trade Annastacia Palaszczuk and the QLD Minister for Health and Ambulance Services Yvette D'Ath announced that ""The Greater Brisbane region has now entered a three-day lockdown and increased restrictions are in place across Queensland as evidence of community transmission of the UK strain of COVID-19 continues to emerge.""  Further that ""From 5pm Monday 29 March to 5pm Thursday 1 April 2021, people in Greater Brisbane (Brisbane City Council, Logan City Council, Moreton Bay Regional Council, Ipswich City Council and Redland City Council) will be required to stay at home except for essential reasons. The restrictions will be reviewed on Wednesday night.""  ""You can only leave your residence (which includes temporary accommodation such as a holiday rental) for limited permitted purposes such as:  obtaining essential goods or services, including healthcare  exercise   attending essential work or childcare  assisting vulnerable persons  You should stay in your local area wherever possible. ""      https://web.archive.org/web/20210331051600/https://statements.qld.gov.au/statements/91825      https://web.archive.org/web/20210404010601/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-03-30/brisbane-lockdown-rules-mask-essential-shopping-school-gathering/100037408     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404011313/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-impacted-areas-3

Queensland: A joint statement by the Premier and Minister for Trade Annastacia Palaszczuk and Minister for Health and Ambulance Services Yvette D'Ath published Thursday, 01 April, 2021 at 01:26 PM states that ""Greater Brisbane’s lockdown ended at 12 noon today....Importantly, a number of restrictions will be put in place for all Queenslanders to protect against further transmission of COVID-19 for the next two weeks.""  No stay at home order remains in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404071525/https://statements.qld.gov.au/statements/91833

There are currently no stay at home directions within Australia.   Below are included archived URLs to official state and territory COVID-19 government website substantiating that there are no current stay at home orders.  This is up to date as of 23rd April 2021.     New South Wales:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423033805/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/covid-19-rules-nsw/what-you-can-do-nsw   Victoria:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423031503/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-live   Queensland:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423033942/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/urgent-covid-19-update   Western Australia:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210420072233/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do   Tasmania:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423034151/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/current-restrictions   Northern Territory:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423034309/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/business-and-work/business/guidelines-for-events-and-gatherings   Australian Capital Territory:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423034405/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/what-you-can-do/what-you-can-do

Snap lockdown - ""People in the Perth and Peel regions will not be able to leave home for the next three days except for essential reasons, including work where it is not possible to work from home, shopping for essentials, and exercise with a maximum of four people for an hour.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210425131432/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/apr/23/perth-to-enter-snap-three-day-lockdown-after-covid-spreads-from-hotel-quarantine-into-community

In a Press Release on Friday, 26 March 2021, Western Australian Premier Mark McGowan announces that ""New Directions are being issued immediately following the recent reported positive COVID-19 case in Brisbane."".  ""All travellers from Queensland who have visited the following locations during the relevant times should be tested immediately for COVID-19 and self-quarantine for 14 days from the time they were at the high-risk location.  These travellers will also be required to undertake a day 11 test.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404021514/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/03/Public-health-alert-for-Queensland-arrivals-into-WA-since-March-20.aspx

In a Press Release on Friday, 27 March 2021, Western Australian Premier Mark McGowan announces that   ""Effective immediately all new arrivals from Queensland will be required to be tested for COVID-19 immediately (within 48 hours) and self-quarantine for 14 days or until a negative test result is returned.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404021026/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/03/Updated-public-health-alert-for-Queensland.aspx

In a Press Release on Friday, 29 March 2021, Western Australian Premier Mark McGowan announces that   ""Following updated advice from the WA Chief Health Officer this morning, Queensland will transition from a 'low risk' State to a 'medium risk' State under WA's controlled interstate border regime, from 12.01am tomorrow (March 30, 2021).  Travel from Queensland will no longer be permitted, unless you are an exempt traveller. This also applies to anyone who may have been in Queensland since March 27 and has not completed 14 days in a 'very low risk' State or Territory. ""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404022245/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/03/WA-introduces-hard-border-with-Queensland-immediately.aspx

Travel restrictions vary by Australian States and Territories.  These are the restrictions in place for each jurisdiction on 9th April 2021.      New South Wales:   According to the NSW Government COVID19 website “There are currently no quarantine requirements for travellers who are already in Australia who are entering NSW from other states.”  However, “Some areas in Queensland are considered affected areas”   Effected areas are specific venues on specific days and times (and can be view at the archives link below).    The government website further states that “After arriving in NSW, or if you are already in NSW and have been to a close contact venue, at the time and date listed in the concerns notice you must  immediately travel to your place of residence or another suitable place  self-isolate for 14 days.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409034241/https://www.nsw.gov.au/quarantine/planning-your-trip  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407094946/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/border-restrictions   https://web.archive.org/web/20210409034330/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Documents/interstate-concerns-notice.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409034446/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/interstate-hotspots    Victoria:   According to the Victorian Government COVID-19 website   “The Greater Brisbane area (City of Brisbane, City of Ipswich, Logan City, Moreton Bay Region, Redlands City) is designated an orange zone under Victoria’s travel permit system, effective from 6:00pm Victorian time on Thursday 1 April.”…” The Gladstone Region in Queensland and Byron Shire in NSW remain as orange zones under the travel permit system.”  “Those travelling from a designated orange zone must apply for a permit to enter Victoria. You cannot apply for a permit if you have COVID-19 symptoms, nor if you have visited a red zone. You are allowed to travel through a red zone for the purpose of transit. In order to enter Victoria, you must agree to the requirement of self-quarantine, get a COVID-19 test within 72 hours of arrival and remain in self-quarantine until you receive a negative test result.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409035021/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/victorian-travel-permit-system   Queensland:   The QLD COVID-19 government website states that “You do not need a border pass to enter Queensland from any Australian state or territory.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409035306/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/government-actions/border-closing     Western Australia:   The WA Government COVID-19 website states that “Effective 12.01am, Wednesday 7 April, travel from Queensland to WA is permitted, subject to 14 days of self-quarantine and COVID-19 testing.” This represents a moderate easing of restrictions.  Previously no traveller were permitted to enter WA from QLD.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210409035635/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/covid-communications/covid-19-coronavirus-controlled-interstate-border     Tasmania:   According to the Tasmanian Government COVID-19 website, there are some “high risk premises” identified within NSW and QLD.    “Travellers who have been at any of the high-risk premises listed at the specified times below are not permitted to enter Tasmania.”  LIf you are currently in Tasmania and have been at any of the Queensland or NSW premises on the dates and times identified below, you must self-isolate immediately and contact the Public Health Hotline. You will be required to have a COVID-19 test and quarantine for 14 days regardless of your test result”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409040101/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409040428/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania/travel-alert    Northern Territory:   The Northern Territory Government website states “There are no current active hotspots.”  Northern Territory hotspot declarations have implications for interstate travel.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210409040610/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409040712/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19/former-declared-hotspots   Australian Capital Territory:   The ACT government Public Health (COVID-19 Areas of Concern) Notice 2021 (No 14) currently states that there are “No areas declared”.  Declared areas have implications for interstate travel.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210409040752/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0009/1738773/COVID-19-Areas-of-Concern-notice_9-April-2021-No-14.pdf

Western Australia:   In an easing of restrictions, and according to the Western Australian COVID-19 Government website, Queensland transitioned from a ‘Low risk’ state to a ‘Very low risk’ state from 12.01am April 19th 2020.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210419140209/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/controlled-interstate-border-changes-queensland    Requirements for individuals entering WA from Very Low Risk jurisdictions are:   “Before travelling to WA, complete a mandatory G2G PASS registration and declaration.  If travelling by air, you must wear a mask on your flight while in WA airspace, and while inside the airport (with some exceptions – e.g. children under the age of 12 are not required to wear a mask).  Complete a health screening on arrival.  Scan your G2G PASS to exit the airport.  No quarantine required.”    Requirements for individuals entering WA from Low Risk jurisdictions are:   “Before travelling to WA, complete a mandatory G2G PASS registration and declaration.  Complete a health screening on arrival.  Scan your G2G PASS and then verify you have suitable premises for self-quarantine.  If you have suitable premises, enter self-quarantine for 14 days. If not, you will be directed to enter a Government-approved quarantine facility at your own expense for 14 days.  You must wear a mask from when you enter WA until you arrive at suitable self-quarantine premises or government approved quarantine facilities. In addition if travelling by air, you must also wear a mask on the flight while in WA airspace, and while inside the airport (with some exceptions – e.g. children under the age of 12 are not required to wear a mask).  You must present for a COVID-19 test on Day 11 if still in WA.”   http://web.archive.org/web/20210419140547/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/covid-communications/covid-19-coronavirus-controlled-border

T1 code reflects Western Australia continuing intra state travel restrictions.        New South Wales:   As documented on the NSW Government COVID-19 Website on the 12th April 2021l five local government areas (forming a part of Brisbane city QLD) were considered Affected Areas.  This remains up to date as of the 23rd April 2021.  Individuals traveling from Affected Areas are allow to enter NSW.  They must complete the declaration form either 24 hours before entry to NSW or on entry.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210423035934/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Documents/interstate-concerns-notice.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423040253/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/interstate-hotspots     Victoria:   According to the VIC Government COVID-19 Website  “Based on an assessment of public health risks, the Chief Health Officer has declared the following areas will be designated green zones under Victoria’s ‘traffic light’ travel permit system effective 11:59pm, 11 April 2021:  Greater Brisbane (City of Brisbane, City of Ipswich, Logan City, Moreton Bay Region, Redlands City)   The Gladstone region in Queensland   Byron Shire in New South Wales”    This is up to date on the 23rd April 2021. There are no VIC Govt declared Orange or Red zones and therefore no inter or intra state travel restrictions.    web.archive.org/web/20210423040908/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/victorian-travel-permit-system    Queensland:   According to the VIC Government COVID-19 Website restrictions eased for all of QLD from 6am Thursday 15 April 2021.  Since this time there has been no intrastate or interstate travel restrictions in place.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210423040919/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/government-actions/border-closing   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423041041/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/hotspots-covid-19     Western Australia:   In an easing of restrictions, and according to the Western Australian COVID-19 Government website, Queensland transitioned from a ‘Low risk’ state to a ‘Very low risk’ state from 12.01am April 19th 2020.  This is up to date as of the 23rd April 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423041457/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/controlled-interstate-border-changes-queensland     Requirements for individuals entering WA from Very Low Risk jurisdictions are:   “Before travelling to WA, complete a mandatory G2G PASS registration and declaration.  If travelling by air, you must wear a mask on your flight while in WA airspace, and while inside the airport (with some exceptions – e.g. children under the age of 12 are not required to wear a mask).  Complete a health screening on arrival.  Scan your G2G PASS to exit the airport.  No quarantine required.”    Requirements for individuals entering WA from Low Risk jurisdictions are:   “Before travelling to WA, complete a mandatory G2G PASS registration and declaration.  Complete a health screening on arrival.  Scan your G2G PASS and then verify you have suitable premises for self-quarantine.  If you have suitable premises, enter self-quarantine for 14 days. If not, you will be directed to enter a Government-approved quarantine facility at your own expense for 14 days.  You must wear a mask from when you enter WA until you arrive at suitable self-quarantine premises or government approved quarantine facilities. In addition if travelling by air, you must also wear a mask on the flight while in WA airspace, and while inside the airport (with some exceptions – e.g. children under the age of 12 are not required to wear a mask).  You must present for a COVID-19 test on Day 11 if still in WA.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423041556/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/covid-communications/covid-19-coronavirus-controlled-border     However, WA continues to implement policies restricting intrastate movement.  The WA Government COVID-19 website states:  There are more than 200 remote Aboriginal communities who are more vulnerable to COVID-19 than other Western Australians.  To help keep the communities safe from COVID-19, there are strict travel restrictions in place.”   Under the WA Government’s Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions, the only people who can enter a remote Aboriginal community are residents of those communities and those who are:  providing essential services and supplies  going to work or school there  entering for family or cultural reasons  delivering a community program or activity  entering in an emergency.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423041734/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-remote-aboriginal-communities-travel   http://web.archive.org/web/20210420072233/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do     Tasmania:   From the 13th April 2021 and current up to 23rd April 2021, the Tasmanian COVID-19 Government Website shows that there are no inter state travel restrictions issued.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423042005/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania     Northern Territory:   According to the Norther Territory COVID-19 website there are no currently declared hotspots, which is up to date as of 23rd April 2021.  There most recently declared NT Govt declared hotspot ended on 3:00pm on 1 April 2021.  Therefore there has been not intra or interstate travel restrictions since 1st April 2021 and current as of 23rd April 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423043701/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423043857/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19/former-declared-hotspots    There are currently no COVID-19 specific intra state travel restrictions within the NT.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423044526/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/remote-work-and-travel   Australian Capital Territory:   The Australian Capital Territory Government website states on the 23rd of April 2021 that there is currently “no areas of concern”.  This has been the policy of the ACT Government since 1pm on 1st April 2021, when all travel restrictions on travellers from the Greater Brisbane Area were lifted.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210423044602/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/updates/covid-19-areas-of-concern   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423044840/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/news-articles/act-travel-restrictions-reduced-for-greater-brisbane

Snap lockdown, restrictions on movement in and out of Perth and Peel. Up to date as of 9th April 2021 - Other than quarantine-free flights from New Zealand, Australia's boarders are closed to non-citizens (with very limited exception). Full details can be read at updated archived link below to the Australian Government Home Affairs website.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210410032643/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions

As published on the Australian Government Home affairs website, “quarantine free travel between Australia and New Zealand will commence at 21:59 AEST on 18 April 2021. All travellers who have been in either Australia or New Zealand for 14 days can travel by air between Australia and New Zealand quarantine free, without the need to apply for a travel exemption. This includes travellers who have spent all 14 days in either safe travel zone country, or people who have travelled between the two countries and are returning within the 14 day period.” Previously individuals could travel from New Zealand to Australia quarantine free BUT individuals from Australia could not travel to New Zealand Quarantine free.  This policy change represents a modest loosening of border restrictions.    However, other than quarantine-free flights from New Zealand, Australia's boarders are closed to non-citizens (with very limited exception).  As such, continuing to code as a 4.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423034950/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423035333/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/new-zealand-safe-travel-zone

This policy change represents a modest loosening of border restrictions. According to the Australian Government Services Australia website, the ""JobKeeper Payment stopped 28 March 2021.""  and ""The temporary Coronavirus Supplement, at a rate of $150 per fortnight, ended on 31 March 2021.""    The JobKeeper Payment was open to eligible employers so they can continue to pay their eligible employees and restart quickly when the COVID-19 crisis is over.  This payment ceased on the 28th March 2021.  The Coronavirus Supplement which was most recently of a rate of $150 per fortnight and provided to individuals receiving study allowances and unemployment benefits will end of the 31st of March 2021.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210404080426/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/subjects/getting-help-during-coronavirus-covid-19/payments-and-services-during-coronavirus/if-you-get-payment/im-job-seeker  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404080941/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/news/jobkeeper-payment-ends-28-march-2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20210313205942/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/subjects/getting-help-during-coronavirus-covid-19/payments-and-services-during-coronavirus/if-you-need-payment

The below note made on the 26th Feb remains up to date as of 26th March 2021.  I have included updated links here.      Currently, as at the 26th March 2021, each state and territory has somewhat different household level debt and contact relief COVID-19 Reponses in place.  However, the only type of COVID-19 related household relief that appears to apply across all jurisdictions is in relation to residential rental payments and/or contracts.     ACT:   According to the ACT government website, and current as at 26th March 2021: The annual increase will not be applied to 2020-2021 annual rates bills, The ACT Revenue Office will implement a new process for rates deferrals for owner occupiers experiencing hardship because of COVID-19. No interest will apply to the deferred amount, The Government is providing land tax and rates rebates to landlords of residential properties who reduce rents by at least 25 per cent for tenants impacted by COVID-19, The ACT Government is offering stamp duty concessions in the ACT for some home buyers planning to live in their new property, All 2020-21 vehicle registration, parking and public transport fee increases at the current levels., Households already receiving the Utilities Concession will receive an additional $200 rebate through their electricity bill, The government will freeze the Utilities Network Facilities Tax (UNFT) at the current  level.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102021/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/business-and-work/economic-survival-package/families-and-households   NSW:  According to the ACT government website, and current as at 26th March 2021: measures to restrict when landlords can evict tenants due to rental arrears as a result of COVID-19;   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326101357/https://www.fairtrading.nsw.gov.au/resource-library/publications/coronavirus-covid-19/property/moratorium   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326101958/https://www.nsw.gov.au/life-events     QLD:   According to the QLD government website, and current as at 26th March 2021:   There remain some temporary regulatory measures to 30 April 2021 means Queensland remains ready to respond to COVID-19 risks as the transition back to normal residential tenancy arrangements continues.  These are: provisions allowing tenants experiencing domestic and family violence to end their tenancies quickly; protections for tenants against being listed in a tenancy database for rent arrears caused by COVID-19 impacts; limits on reletting costs for eligible tenants who end their fixed term tenancies early; short term tenancy statement extensions for moveable dwellings; entry restrictions and requirements to support COVID-19 social distancing measures; relaxed repair and maintenance obligations.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210326102104/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/the-hub/covid-19-tenancy-update    VIC:   According to The Victorian Government website, and current as at 26th March 2021, COVID-19 changes to renting laws (implemented 29 March 2020 and still in effect) mean that tenants in financial hardship cannot be given a notice to vacate; landlords must try to negotiated a temporary rent reduction agreement where it is needed by tenants because of the impacts of COVID-19. Tenants can apply for a rent relief grant of up to $3,000.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102308/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/renting-laws-and-support-during-coronavirus-covid-19-pandemic    NT:  According to The Northern Territory Consumer Affairs website, and current as at 26th March 2021 “On 24 April 2020, the Northern Territory Parliament passed the Tenancies Legislation Amendment Act 2020. This provides the framework for the Territory’s response to tenancy issues arising as a result of the COVID-19 emergency.” These modifications: Extending notice timeframes for certain pre termination actions under the Act; establish New processes for termination of a tenancy; and provide for modified entry and inspection processes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102313/https://consumeraffairs.nt.gov.au/rental-changes-due-to-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102331/https://nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0010/818308/s28.pdf    WA: According to The Western Australian Government website, and current as at 26th March 2021” “In response to COVID-19, the Western Australian Government implemented a moratorium on some evictions and all rent increases, under the Residential Tenancies (COVID-19 Response) Act 2020. The extended emergency period ends on 28 March 2021, which means that all the existing laws will stay in place until this date, after which the ordinary tenancy laws will apply again.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102604/https://www.commerce.wa.gov.au/consumer-protection/residential-tenancies-covid-19-response   SA:  According to SA Government COVID-19 website, and current as at 26th March 2021 “State Parliament has endorsed a number of initiatives aimed at helping landlords and tenants whose incomes have been affected by COVID-19.” This includes “Ensuring tenants cannot be evicted by landlords due to an inability to paid rent because of COVID-19 employment loss”.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102653/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/school-and-community/housing-and-in-the-community    TA:   According to The Northern Territory Consumer Affairs website, and current as at 26th March 2021.  “Some of the changes to the Residential Tenancy Act 1997 including changes to rental evictions, rental increases, and general repairs and maintenance expired on 31 January 2021.” However, The Tasmanian Government is providing rent relief for residential households who rent homes in the private market and who are experiencing housing stress because of the impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19).  The Support Funds are available until 31 March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102826/https://www.coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/rental-housing

Western Australia: As documented in the note on the 26th March 2021  ""According to The Western Australian Government website, and current as at 26th March 2021” “In response to COVID-19, the Western Australian Government implemented a moratorium on some evictions and all rent increases, under the Residential Tenancies (COVID-19 Response) Act 2020. The extended emergency period ends on 28 March 2021, which means that all the existing laws will stay in place until this date, after which the ordinary tenancy laws will apply again.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102604/https://www.commerce.wa.gov.au/consumer-protection/residential-tenancies-covid-19-response""    The Western Australian Government website, current at 4th April 2021 now states that ""The extended COVID-19 emergency period has ended, which means the ordinary tenancy laws under the Residential Tenancies Act 1987 (WA) apply again. ""    Yes, if rent arrears have accrued during the emergency period, tenants experiencing financial hardship can apply for a grant of 75 per cent of the debt, up to $4,000, paid directly to their landlord. In return, the landlord and tenant must agree to enter into a lease agreement for at least six months beyond 29 March 2021. Visit the Residential Rent Relief Grant Scheme page for more information.  However, the moratorium on some evictions and all rent increases has now ceased.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404084211/https://www.commerce.wa.gov.au/consumer-protection/residential-tenancies-covid-19-response       Due to this reduction in debt/contract relief within Western Australia, household debt/contract relief is no longer available (as a government policy response to COVID-19) across all Australian jurisdictions.  Therefore changed E2 code to 0.

Up to date as of the 19th April 2021 there continues to be no nation wide household debt/contract relief available in response to COVID-19. Updated archived comments and URLS provided. Some support remains in some, but not all Australian state/territory jurisdictions.  Therefore a zero is coded.
