'The Centre for Health Protection today [9 April 2021] said all asymptomatic residents living in units 09 on all floors of Block 3, Oi Fai House, Yau Oi Estate in Tuen Mun have to be quarantined.  Two confirmed and two preliminary positive COVID-19 cases were recently detected at four units in Block 3 of Oi Fai House.  The centre co-ordinated with related government departments and conducted a site inspection this evening of the floors and units concerned to investigate and examine if environmental factors were involved in the infections.  Taking into account the opinions of experts, the centre decided to carry out prudent infection control measures.  All asymptomatic residents of units 09 on all floors of Block 3, Oi Fai House will be transferred to quarantine centres, while symptomatic residents will be sent to hospital for treatment.'    https://archive.vn/lcg5a
No change in policy.
No change in policy.

Travellers from China testing adjustments set    According to the notice, any person aged six or above who arrives in Hong Kong from April 1 via any land boundary control point and is placed under quarantine under the relevant regulation, as well as those arriving in Hong Kong under the Return2hk Scheme and are hence exempted from compulsory quarantine, must undergo testing on the second and 12th day following their arrival in the city.     Meanwhile, people who arrive in Hong Kong via the airport and are placed under quarantine must also undergo testing on the 12th day following their arrival in addition to the test-and-hold arrangement on the day of arrival.    https://archive.ph/PrB4v#selection-611.0-619.223

'The Government is preparing to relax the compulsory quarantine requirement for people arriving in Hong Kong from overseas and the Mainland.  Chief Executive Carrie Lam made the announcement at a press conference this afternoon [i.e. 12 April 2021], noting that the quarantine period for those from low-risk countries can be shortened to seven days.'    https://archive.vn/U2Xnk

The Government announced today it will tighten the measures for travellers who have stayed in Egypt within 21 days before they board for Hong Kong. People arriving in Hong Kong from Egypt on the day of arrival or during the 21 days before that day are required to present before boarding proof of a nucleic acid test for COVID-19 negative result conducted within 72 hours before the aircraft's scheduled time of departure. They also have to present confirmation of a room reservation in a designated quarantine hotel in Hong Kong for not less than 21 nights starting on the day of the arrival.    https://archive.ph/V85yr

The Food & Health Bureau explained that starting April 14, the Government began implementing the tightened commercial flight suspension mechanism to address the risk of importation of mutant strains of COVID-19 from very high-risk places. The Government also announced a plan to shorten the quarantine period for fully vaccinated people arriving from places overseas that are not considered high risk on the basis of the vaccine bubble.    If five or more passengers among all flights from the same place, regardless of airline, are confirmed by arrival tests for COVID-19 with the N501Y mutant strain within a seven-day period, the Government would prohibit all passenger flights from that place from landing in Hong Kong for 14 days.    https://archive.ph/39S6x    The details about the quarantine arrangement were stated in the following archived link:    https://archive.ph/AM7wo

The Government today announced that it invoked the place-specific flight suspension mechanism for India, Pakistan and the Philippines. From midnight on April 20, all passenger flights from such places will be prohibited from landing in Hong Kong for 14 days. These places will also be specified as extremely high-risk places to restrict people who have stayed there from boarding for Hong Kong. The suspension will be effective for 14 days.    Additionally, the Government will issue a compulsory testing notice for people who returned to Hong Kong from extremely high-risk places, ie Group A specified places, to enhance the testing of those returning to Hong Kong from overseas places. After completing the compulsory quarantine for 21 days as well as testing on the 12th and 19th day during quarantine, these people will also need to self-monitor further for another seven days and be subject to COVID-19 nucleic acid testing on the 26th day of their return to the city.    https://archive.ph/loot9    https://archive.ph/p0foU

""The government plans to keep schools open in prefectures placed under a COVID-19 state of emergency in an effort to avoid interrupting education, officials have said. Education ministry guidelines say that region-wide school closures due to the pandemic should be avoided from the viewpoint of ensuring healthy learning and for the mental and physical health of children.""    HOWEVER - ""In the city of Osaka, the board of education plans to introduce online classes, with some students coming to school for part of the day. For online classes, students will use tablets and other devices distributed to all 160,000 pupils attending municipal elementary and junior high schools.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423223508/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/04/23/national/japan-emergency-schools/

New measures in Osaka, Hyogo and Miyagi prefectures: ""The steps, effective for one month until May 5, include fines for restaurants that ignore orders to shorten operating hours and requirements for customers to wear masks when patronizing such establishments."" http://web.archive.org/web/20210407073749/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/04/05/national/osaka-hyogo-miyagi-stronger-measures-start/  Reduced hours or restaurants, karaoke bars and other businesses continue in Tokyo until April 21. https://archive.ph/17E4z

New measures announced which will take effect Monday: ""Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga on Friday approved stricter measures to stamp out soaring coronavirus cases for Tokyo, Okinawa and Kyoto — effective Monday — as variants pose a fresh threat to a public already frazzled by monthslong restrictions.  The measures authorize prefectural governors to request and order establishments, primarily bars and restaurants, to close by 8 p.m. in designated municipalities, as opposed to the prefecture-wide implementation seen in a state of emergency. They will be in place in all of the capital’s 23 wards and six cities — Musashino, Hachioji, Machida, Chofu, Fuchu and Tachikawa — through May 11, while they will be implemented in the city of Kyoto and nine cities in Okinawa Prefecture — Naha, Nago, Uruma, Okinawa, Ginowan, Urasoe, Tomigusuku, Itoman and Nanjo — until May 5.""   http://web.archive.org/web/20210409112108/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/04/09/national/tokyo-kyoto-okinawa-covid-19-measures/

Japan declared a state of emergency from April 25 - May 11 with restrictions in Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Hyogo prefectures. Establishments that sell alcohol or offer karaoke will be asked to close or face fines. While closure is technically voluntary, the fact that local leaders in these prefectures requested the measures and the imposition of fines means that in practice there is a requirement to close these sectors.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210426091312/https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2021/04/23/990133421/japan-declares-3rd-state-of-emergency-3-months-ahead-of-olympics?t=1619428221199

Ministry of Finance (MOF) decided to use safety net loan(loan limit:JPY720million) and  loan for crisis response(loan limit: JPY300million)  to support SMEs. Low interest rate loan provided by government financial institutions (JFC, Shoko Chukin Bank etc.). The government established private financial institution’s no-interest unsecured loan provided by utilizing prefectural directed credit programs. The loan limit is JPY30million. Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) established subsidy program for sustaining businesses. This program targets companies facing severe conditions in particular and provides them with subsidies for a wide variety of purposes that in general are considered effective in supporting them in sustaining or reviving their businesses. Eligible companies can obtain JPY 2 million (Maximum).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406144337/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/japan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html

A. The vaccination period is scheduled to start on February 17, 2021 and end on February 30, 2022. Medical personnel and healthcare professionals will first be vaccinated. After this, vaccinations are expected to be given to the elderly and those with underlying conditions. The vaccination of the elderly is expected to start on April 12 in some municipalities. Initially, the number of cities, towns, and villages where the vaccination will be conducted  and the number of people to be vaccinated will be limited, but will gradually expand.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406143225/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kenkou-iryousoudan_00006.html#1-1

Cambodia continues to temporarily suspend cinemas, art theaters and museums. Authorities have also closed certain businesses and buildings in response to the current outbreak (known as the “February 20 incident”). Phnom Penh has implemented a daily curfew from 8:00 pm to 5:00 am effective from April 1 through April 14, 2021. The curfew suspends in-person restaurant and food stall service and forbids most types of gatherings and travel within the city during curfew hours. Exceptions to restrictions during curfew hours include travel for emergency medical need, gatherings with family members, and travel for work for those businesses permitted to remain open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412191011/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Phnom Penh (until Apr 28), Banteay Meanchey province (until Apr 20), Tboung Khmum province (until Apr 20), Siem Reap province (until Apr 23), Kampot province (until Apr 21) all continue to implement daily curfews from 8:00 pm to 5:00 am.  In addition, Phnom Penh and Ta Khmau municipalities have further lockdown measures where all individuals within the lockdown areas must not leave their residence for the duration of the lockdown period, with some exceptions:  - Up to two individuals per household are permitted to leave their residence to purchase food from the nearest shop in their neighborhood, but may do so no more than three times a week and must have a valid form of identification with them.  - Individuals are permitted to leave their residence to purchase medicine as necessary.  - Groups of up to four people may travel to seek medical care within or outside the lockdown area, but require a letter of permission from the local authorities.  - Certain essential businesses may remain open despite the lockdown but may be subject to restrictions such as minimizing staffing to no more than 2%. Travel to work in these businesses requires a travel permit.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418195753/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Three villages in Phnom Penh have additional ""red zone"" lockdown measures imposed, effective April 16 to April 29: All individuals within the “Red Zones” must not leave their residence, except for medical emergencies, for COVID-19 testing as directed by the relevant authorities, or to receive a second dose of the COVID-19 vaccine as determined by the relevant authorities. These villages are as follows: Sangkat Stueng Meanchey 1, Stueng Meanchey 2, Stueng Meanchey 3; Sangkat Chaom Chau; Villages 14, 16, and 17 in Sangkat Boeng Salang.  Lockdown measures with some exceptions imposed on Phnom Penh and Ta Khmau municipalities are effective through April 28, 2021 and until April 29 for three districts in Siem Reap.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426203851/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Cambodian government announced a 14-day prohibition on all travel between provinces, effective 12:00 a.m. April 7 until April 20, 2021. This prohibition is applicable to travel between all provinces, except for travel between Phnom Penh and Kandal province.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412191011/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Cambodian government continues to prohibit all travel between provinces from April 7 until April 28, 2021. This prohibition is applicable to travel between all provinces, except for travel between Phnom Penh and Kandal province. Travel to seek medical attention in personal vehicles (up to four people) and ambulances are exempt from this travel prohibition.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418195753/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Cambodian government continues to prohibit all travel between provinces from April 7 until April 28, 2021. This prohibition is applicable to travel between all provinces, except for travel between Phnom Penh and Kandal province. Travel to seek medical attention in personal vehicles (up to four people) and ambulances are exempt from this travel prohibition.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426203851/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travelers into Cambodia must present a valid visa issued by a Cambodian Embassy or Consulate.? The Government of Cambodia has suspended the e-visa and visa-on-arrival programs until further notice.   In addtion, entry must also follow the following guidelines:  - Possess a negative medical certificate for COVID-19 no more than 72-hours prior to the date of arrival.  - Undergo a COVID-19 test upon arrival and wait in official facilities/designated hotels to receive laboratory results.? Health authorities will then oversee another COVID-19 test on the 13th day of quarantine.   - Fully abide by locally enforced quarantine measures for 14 days at a hotel designated by the Government of Cambodia.   - Pay a deposit of $2,000 upon arrival at airports for mandatory COVID-19 testing and potential treatment services. ?The money will be used to pay for an accommodation during the quarantine, testing and transportation from an airport to a hotel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418195753/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travelers into Cambodia must continue to present a valid visa issued by a Cambodian Embassy or Consulate. The Government of Cambodia has suspended the e-visa and visa-on-arrival programs until further notice.   In addition, entry must also follow the following guidelines:  - Possess a negative medical certificate for COVID-19 no more than 72-hours prior to the date of arrival.  - Undergo a COVID-19 test upon arrival and wait in official facilities/designated hotels to receive laboratory results.? Health authorities will then oversee another COVID-19 test on the 13th day of quarantine.   - Fully abide by locally enforced quarantine measures for 14 days at a hotel designated by the Government of Cambodia.   - Pay a deposit of $2,000 upon arrival at airports for mandatory COVID-19 testing and potential treatment services. ?The money will be used to pay for an accommodation during the quarantine, testing and transportation from an airport to a hotel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426203851/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

In March 2021, the government has extended until the end of June 2021 this year for: i) allowance subsidy for garment and tourism sectors; ii) tax exemption for tourism and aviation sector; and iii) cash relief program for poor and vulnerable families.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418054857/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Due to the February 20 Community Transmission Event, the Cambodian government is calling on anyone who has been at specified places such as all workers from a garment factory in Meanchey, visitors to Samhan Toul Sangke market, and a number of other locations found to have an individual test postiive.  In addition, anyone with symptoms of fever, cough, sneezing, running nose, tiredness and or shortness of breath should get tested for the virus immediately.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419005109/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/839896/shoppers-and-visitors-to-samhan-toul-sangke-market-between-april-05-and-april-10-should-get-tested-for-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419005031/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/?s=test

A,B,C (Sinovax, Sinopharm, AstraZeneca): The first day of Sinovax vaccination campaign begins April 1 after receiving 1.5 million doses from China. People considered as vulnerable and front liners are still prioritised in the vaccination campaign. Among the priority groups are health workers, journalists, police and military personnel, government officials and factory workers. Priority campaign for the elderly began March 23.  Currently, Cambodia has three kinds of vaccines in Sinopharm, AstraZeneca/SII (COVISHIELD), and Sinovax.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419014153/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50833455/nearly-20000-inoculated-on-the-first-day-of-sinovac-vaccination-campaign/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419014646/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50834563/some-140000-people-get-sinovac-vaccines/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419015209/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50829110/drive-to-protect-elderly-15-day-vaccination-campaign-begins-in-earnest/

A,B,C (Sinovax, AstraZeneca, Sinopharm): As of April 17, more than 1.24 million people have been vaccinated against COVID-19 since the first shots were given on February 10.  Priority groups continue to be the elderly, the vulnerable, and frontliners including health workers, journalists, police and military personnel, government officials and factory workers.  The vaccines delivered are Sinopharm – 1.3 million doses, Sinovac 1.5 million doses and Astra Zenecca through the Covax initiative, 324,000 doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419021414/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50840072/vaccinations-for-covid-19-suspended-for-three-days-from-today-to-monday-resumes-on-tuesday/

Cambodia will be administering the second dose of Sinovac vaccinations from April 24 to April 30 for people living in Tuol Kork district. They will be able to receive their second dose without having to cross district boundaries. Priority groups continue to be the elderly, the vulnerable, and frontliners including health workers, journalists, police and military personnel, government officials and factory workers.  The National Committee for COVID-19 Vaccination has also asked local authorities to list the names of anyone living in a Red Zone waiting for their second dose to prepare a vaccination programme for them.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210427055613/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50844214/new-location-for-vaccines-in-toul-kork-district/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419021414/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50840072/vaccinations-for-covid-19-suspended-for-three-days-from-today-to-monday-resumes-on-tuesday/

Announced April 22, the government of Laos has closed its borders and announced a two-week lockdown in the capital, Vientiane, and restrictions in other provinces until May 5 as the country weathers a rare outbreak of COVID-19 linked to its neighbor Thailand.  Entertainment venues such as karaoke or beer bars, internet cafes, spas and massage places, fitness venues and all indoor sports facilities are ordered closed. The following entities are allowed to continue to operate: factories, banks and other financial institutions, the stock exchange, hospitals and medical centers, pharmacies, medical emergency services, postal service, telecommunication, electricity providers, water supply facilities, waste collectors, agricultural markets, convenience stores, supermarkets, gas stations, restaurants and coffee shops.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210421214936/https://www.rfa.org/english/news/laos/cases-04212021171654.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426190809/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
large gatherings and religious ceremonies are permitted  http://web.archive.org/web/20210405182250/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Due to the 2-week lockdown announced April 22 to May 5, travel is prohibited from the Vientiane Capital district to the provinces. Travel into Vientiane Capital district is also prohibited except for returning residents, those who work in the capital, or who have obtained special permission from the COVID-19 Task Force.  Transportation to and from the capital district is suspended and the police will set up checkpoints to enforce the order.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210421214936/https://www.rfa.org/english/news/laos/cases-04212021171654.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426190809/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All ground-based border crossings will remain closed except for the transportation of goods. International flights (often to Seoul, Republic of Korea) and weekly UN humanitarian flights (to/from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia) are significantly limited, but operate regularly, with exit flights departing roughly every two weeks and entry flights arriving once or twice per month, depending on demand. Domestic flights continue to be fully operational.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426190809/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Bank of Lao P.D.R. (BOL) has reduced the reserve requirements from 10 to 8 percent on foreign exchange, and from 5 to 4 percent on local currency, effective April 2. A new credit policy for those impacted, asking banks and financial institutions to restructure loans and provide new loans to businesses affected by the outbreak has been issued. Under this policy, banks and financial institutions that implement debt restructuring and new loan provisions will benefit from regulatory forbearance on loan classification and provisioning. BOL has also cut its policy rate from 4 to 3 percent for one-week loans; from 5 to 4 percent for one-two week loans; and from 10 to 9 percent for two-week to one-year loans.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426192623/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Lao PDR today received its first shipment of COVID-19 vaccine doses through the COVAX facility, a partnership between the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, UNICEF and the World Health Organisation  The shipment consists of 132,000 doses of the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine, manufactured by the Serum Institute of India (SII), and was shipped by air to the Wattay International Airport in Vientiane from Pune, India. This batch of AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccines is the first of the total of 480,000 doses being planned for delivery to Lao PDR via the COVAX initiative this year to cover about 20 percent of the total population.  According the country’s National Deployment and Vaccination Plan (NVDP), this initial batch of AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccines will be used by the Government of Lao PDR to first immunise priority groups in the country who are at greater risk of exposure to COVID-19 and those who are most likely to develop severe symptoms from infection.    This includes frontline healthcare workers, older adults above the age of 60 and people with underlying health conditions. Some essential workers will also be prioritised based on the nature of the job and high-risk of exposure to COVID-19 such as workers at points of entry and in quarantine centres.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210405183726/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-vaccines-shipped-by-covax-facility-arrive-in-lao-pdr/

The government has begun vaccinating the most vulnerable and at-risk groups in a step towards ending the acute phase of the Covid-19 pandemic.  The national rollout of COVAX-supported vaccines began at Mittaphab Hospital in Vientiane on Friday (April 2).  The vaccines were received on March 20 and were provided by the COVAX Facility, a partnership between the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations, Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, UNICEF, and the World Health Organisation (WHO).  The shipment consisted of 132,000 doses of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine manufactured by the Serum Institute of India.  This shipment is the first of Laos’ initial allocation of 480,000 doses. COVAX aspires to provide enough vaccine to supply at least 20 percent of the population this year, according to a press release from UNICEF.   the priority groups comprise healthcare workers, adults above the age of 60, and people with underlying health conditions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210412183244/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/04/05/laos-mass-rollout-of-covid-19-vaccine-gets-underway
Vaccine open for foreigner as well.    US Web Archived for Embassy: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182114/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A,B,C (AstraZeneca, Sinopharm): Health authorities in Laos have launched an online registration programme for Covid-19 vaccinations aimed at priority groups. According to an announcement by the Centre of Information and Education for Health, residents of Vientiane and foreign citizens will be able to register online for Covid-19 vaccinations. The AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine and Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine will be given to priority groups such as medical personnel and individuals in at-risk groups, as well as people who are 60 years old or above. After medical personnel, individuals with chronic illnesses, such as respiratory or cardiovascular disease, asthma, obesity, immunodeficiency, and others, are expected to receive the vaccine first.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426202227/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/04/24/authorities-open-online-registration-for-covid-19-vaccinations-in-laos

According to the US Embassy in Yangon,    ""Residents of Yangon Region must abide by the following orders: 1.) stay at home unless going to/from work, 2.) employees of private organizations and businesses must telework (those working in banking and finance, gas stations, food and refrigeration services, production and manufacturing of pharmaceutical products, medical equipment production, and the distribution of drinking water and personal hygiene items are exempt), 3.) only one person per household allowed for grocery shopping, 3.) only two people per household allowed for medical treatment, 4.) a mask must be worn at all times when out of the home, 5.) only vehicles transporting people for one of the permitted activities are allowed to pass through other townships, 6.) in addition to the passenger(s), only one driver is allowed in a vehicle for the permitted activities, and 7.) advance approval from the respective ward administration is needed for anything that falls outside of these permitted activities. Failure to comply with this order will warrant action under the Prevention and Control of Communicable Diseases Law..""    See the US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/o0WBl

According to the US Embassy in Myanmar,    ""Is a curfew in place? – YES        The military regime has instituted a ban on gatherings of five or more people, and a nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M. that supersedes previous COVID-19 policies.""    See the US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/o0WBl

Failure to comply with this order will warrant action under the Prevention and Control of Communicable Diseases Law..""    See the US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/o0WBl

According to the US Embassy in Yangon,    ""Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? – YES        Some domestic flights have resumed in Burma. Contact domestic airlines for details about COVID-19 related travel procedures.      Burmese authorities announced stay-at-home orders for all of Yangon Region (except for Coco Island), effective at 8:00 AM on September 21, 2020.    Residents of Yangon Region must abide by the following orders: 1.) stay at home unless going to/from work, 2.) employees of private organizations and businesses must telework (those working in banking and finance, gas stations, food and refrigeration services, production and manufacturing of pharmaceutical products, medical equipment production, and the distribution of drinking water and personal hygiene items are exempt), 3.) only one person per household allowed for grocery shopping, 3.) only two people per household allowed for medical treatment, 4.) a mask must be worn at all times when out of the home, 5.) only vehicles transporting people for one of the permitted activities are allowed to pass through other townships, 6.) in addition to the passenger(s), only one driver is allowed in a vehicle for the permitted activities, and 7.) advance approval from the respective ward administration is needed for anything that falls outside of these permitted activities. Failure to comply with this order will warrant action under the Prevention and Control of Communicable Diseases Law.    Travel restrictions and mandatory public health measures are in force in most parts of Burma. U.S. citizens travelling or resident anywhere in Burma should ensure they have the latest information on COVID-19 prevention measures in the locations they plan to visit, or currently reside in. Note that new measures may be put into place with little or no advance notice.""    See the US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/o0WBl

The suspension of flights into Myanmar has been extended to 30th April 2021.    ""According to the notice from the Department of Civil Aviation issued on 31 March 2021, the earlier restrictions for all international airlines operating air services to and from the Yangon International Airport have been further extended up to 30 April 2021, 2359 Hours MST.""    See the Yangon airport notice, archived at https://archive.vn/ZGufA

In addition to monitoring symptoms, the app provides timely notifications on nearby potential high-risk areas with positive cases, and the official COVID-19 hotlines contacts, closest fever clinics and quarantine center.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322151550/https://eurocham-myanmar.org/post/615/Myanmar-government-developed-a-COVID-19-tracking-App""    However, the Saw Saw Shar website is currently unavailable. According to the US Embassy,     ""Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Burma?  If so, are test results reliably available with 72 hours? – YES        Testing is available at the following locations:      Air Cargo Terminal at Yangon International Airport: located on Pyay Road near the Than Pin Gone bus stop. It is located near the DHL Myanmar warehouse at the airport, which is searchable in Google Maps.      Swab collections for PCR tests occur daily from 9:00 a.m. until 11:00 a.m. with results available the next day by 9:30 a.m.      The cost of the PCR test is 200,000 MMK.      Telephone numbers: 094 4409 9941 / 094 4409 9942 (*We have received reports that phone inquiries may not be answered, but the facility remains open).      N Health: located in Yangon at the Tourist Burma Building on the corner of Maha Bandula St. and Sule Paya St. (near Sule Pagoda).      Swab collections for PCR tests occur daily from 8:00 a.m. until 10:00 a.m. with PCR results available within 24 hours.      The cost of the PCR test is 200,000 MMK.      Telephone numbers: 01 230 3202 / 09 519 9122      Pun Hlaing Hospital: located in Yangon on Pun Hlaing Estate Avenue, Hlaing Tharyar Township, as well as at Pun Hlaing Clinic Downtown Yangon, No. 14/A, Taw Win Street (Corner of Ambassador St and Taw Win St), Dagon Township.      PCR and antigen tests are provided. Please call or register online at least 24 hours in advance.      The cost of the antigen test is 45,000 MMK and the PCR test is 200,000 MMK.      Telephone number: 09 40 060 222      Samitivej International Clinic: located in Yangon at 9E/2 Kabar Aye Pagoda Road, Mayangone Township.      Requirements: copy of air ticket and copy of passport.      Swab collections occur daily from 7:30 a.m. until 10:30 a.m. with results available within 30 hours (via email with hard copy also available for pickup). Please call first before visiting the clinic.      The cost is 420,000 MMK (includes doctor consultation, Fit to Fly certificate, sample collection fees, lab test) or at-home sample collection is available (includes doctor consultation, Fit to Fly certificate, sample collection fees, transportation fees, lab test). Please contact the clinic for at-home pricing.      Antigen tests are also available. Please contact the clinic for details.      Telephone numbers: 01 656 732 / 01 660 545 / 09 42427 4301      International SOS Clinic: located in Yangon at Inya Lake Hotel, 37 Kaba Aye Pagoda Road.      Swab collections for PCR tests are by appointment only. Please call the clinic for more information.      International SOS will set up a tele-consultation with a doctor three days before your flight, with swab collection two days before your flight, and results available the day before your flight.      The cost of the tele-consultation is $63 USD, the PCR swab collection is $55 USD, and the cost for processing of the PCR test result is $143 USD.      Telephone numbers: 01 657 922 / 09 420 114 536      Email: reception.ygn@internationalsos.com      Note: This information may change frequently and without notice. Those seeking a test are advised to contact the lab first before showing up to check on the most recent requirements, policies, and operating hours, or contact us at ACSRangoon@state.gov.""    However it is unclear if this information remains true (and has not been updated) since the coup d'état.    See the US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/o0WBl
No legitimate sources to indicate either way at the point, due to the media blackout as a result of the coup d'état.

Vaccine: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19)    According to the US Embassy,    ""COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Have Burmese authorities approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Are vaccines available in Burma for U.S. citizens to receive? – YES        Burmese authorities previously received approximately 3 million Covidshield/AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine doses in early 2021. These vaccines are being distributed without any public announcement of a vaccination plan. Burmese authorities have not communicated to the U.S. Embassy how or if they will provide this vaccine to foreign nationals residing in Burma.""    However, based on previous information, dated 5th February, health workers and volunteers, as well as select elderly people over the age of 65 has started receiving the vaccine. There has been no further updates on Myanmar Times (the newspaper of record in Myanmar) as it has suspended reporting for three months starting 21 February due to the coup d'état.    See Myanmar Times' reporting on 5th Feb, archived at http://web.archive.org/web/20210412181318/https://www.mmtimes.com/news/more-380000-myanmar-receive-covid-19-vaccine.html  See the US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/o0WBl

No noted changes since last note. Note that due to the coup d'état in Myanmar, Myanmar's largest newspaper (Myanmar Times) has suspended reporting for three months starting 21 February. According to last note, there are recommended protections due to the prioritisation of vaccination for elderly people. ""Around 3000 people over the age of 65 were given the vaccine in Pabedan, Dagon, and Botahtaung townships.""    See http://web.archive.org/web/20210412181318/https://www.mmtimes.com/news/more-380000-myanmar-receive-covid-19-vaccine.html

'All five million students in Malaysia were in school on Monday (April 5). ... While schools started welcoming back students as early as March 1 this year, only pre-schoolers and pupils in primary Years One and Two, followed by those in Year Three to Six a week later, were allowed into their classrooms then under a staggered return.  All secondary school students have resumed schooling on Monday after five months, starting with those in Johor, Kedah, Kelantan and Terengganu on Sunday.  ...  Parents and teachers agree that if there is one lesson to be learnt from the past year living under Covid-19, it is that online learning has been an inadequate substitute for the experience and teaching in physical classrooms. Malaysia on Monday [22 MAR 2021] announced it had established a $2.4 million compensation fund to provide cash assistance for any COVID-19 vaccine recipients who suffer severe reactions due to inoculations.  ...  Under the new fund, individuals requiring extended hospitalisation due to a vaccine reaction will be eligible for 50,000 ringgit ($12,171), or if this results in permanent disability or death 500,000 ringgit, Health Minister Adham Baba said.'    Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced a new economic stimulus package worth RM20 billion (US$4.8 billion) on Wednesday (Mar 17), one year after Malaysia first imposed a lockdown to curb the spread of COVID-19.      https://archive.vn/lrV0B  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419084225/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/malaysia-pm-muhyiddin-rm20-billion-economic-stimulus-covid-19-14428000

'Malaysia will receive a supply of 3.5 million doses of CanSino Covid-19 vaccine from China in stages, starting this month [April], said Health Minister Datuk Seri Dr Adham Baba.  ...  Dr Adham said the CanSino vaccine would be used mainly in rural areas and areas where it was difficult for recipients to receive double injections such as for the Pfizer-BioNTech and Sinovac vaccines.  “This single-dose vaccine can also be used for the purpose of vaccinating foreigners in Malaysia,” he added.  Under the agreement, SolBio will produce three million doses on the fill and finish basis to be supplied to the government.'    https://archive.vn/mbRWW

Under Level 1 domestic controls, the government does not limit gathering size or require businesses to comply with social distancing standards. All companies, including entertainment venues, can operate without staffing or capacity restrictions. Employees may also work on-site at offices. However, all individuals are required to wear facemasks while on public transport nationwide; the mandate affects long-distance bus and train services, ferries, domestic flights, and ride-hailing services.    The government requires all businesses and public facilities nationwide to post quick response (QR) codes at entrances to improve contact tracing, regardless of alert level.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426190603/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/470831/new-zealand-level-1-covid-19-restrictions-remain-in-place-nationwide-as-of-april-24-update-10

An entry ban for most foreign nationals remains in place. Officials permit partners and dependents of citizens who old a visa based on the relationship or who usually reside in New Zealand and diplomats to enter without prior government consent. Authorities also allow partners, dependents, and legal guardians of citizens without visas to enter. Australian citizens and permanent residents of New Zealand, Samoan and Tongan citizens on essential trips approved by their governments, and travelers for humanitarian reasons can also enter the country. Authorities have banned all travelers with a 14-day travel history to India until April 28 in response to an increase in positive COVID-19 cases in that country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426190603/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/470831/new-zealand-level-1-covid-19-restrictions-remain-in-place-nationwide-as-of-april-24-update-10

""If you have cold, flu or COVID-19 symptoms, stay home and call your doctor or Healthline on 0800 358 5453 to see if you need a test.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426190411/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-system/alert-level-1

Health services use contact tracing to find people who may have been exposed to an infectious disease. There are several types of ‘contacts’ – Close Plus  Contacts, Close Contacts, Casual Plus Contacts and Casual Contacts. Health services provide advice to all of these contact types on what they need to do.    ""If you have been identified as a Close or Close Plus Contact of someone with COVID-19, you can expect to be contacted by the Ministry of Health or your PHU.     In some specific higher risk situations, Casual Plus Contacts may also be contacted by the Ministry of Health.     Contact tracing may involve a phone call from the Ministry or PHU providing you with advice on testing, self-isolation and checking on your health and wellbeing. The Ministry call centre staff will identify themselves and inform you that they are calling from the National Investigation and Tracing Centre (NITC). They will also verify your name and contact details. These calls from the Ministry's call centre staff will usually come from 09 801 3009 or 09 306 8748.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426190047/https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-health-advice-public/contact-tracing-covid-19

Effective 29 March 2021 to 4 April 2021, the Philippine government has placed the provinces of Metro Manila, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal and the National Capital Region under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) as stringent limitations on movement. Effective April 1 until April 30, 2021, Santiago City is placed under Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ) as transition period between ECQ and General Community Quarantine (GCQ). Effective April 1 until April 15, 2021, Quirino Province is placed under MECQ. Effective until April 30, 2021 Luzon, the entire Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR); Cagayan, Isabela, and Nueva Vizcaya are placed under MECQ. All other areas are placed under Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ) until end of April 2021. Any person below 18 and above 65 and those with health risks and pregnant women are required to remain at home ‘except when indispensable circumstances for obtaining essential goods and services’. Under ECQ ‘face-to-face classes at all levels shall be suspended.’    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329202012/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/20210328-OMNIBUS-Guidelines-RRD.pdf

Announced April 4, as a continuation of the Enhanced Community Quarantine currently imposed on the provinces of Bulacan, Cavite, laguna, Rizal, and highly urbanized cities of the National Capital Region and Pateros municpality will be extended to April 11, 2021.  Schools continue to be closed due to the curfew directive: Any person below 18 and above 65 and those with health risks and pregnant women are required to remain at home ‘except when indispensable circumstances for obtaining essential goods and services’.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405230551/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210404-Resolution-108A-RRD.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405161557/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Enhanced Community Quarantine currently imposed on the provinces of Abra, Bulacan, Cavite, laguna, Rizal, and highly urbanized cities of the National Capital Region and Pateros municipality will continue from April 12 to April 30, 2021.  Schools remain to be closed due to the curfew directive: Any person below 18 and above 65 and those with health risks and pregnant women are required to remain at home ‘except when indispensable circumstances for obtaining essential goods and services’.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412031525/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210410-IATF-RESOLUTION-109-A.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405230551/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210404-Resolution-108A-RRD.pdf

Areas placed under ECQ (Enhanced Community Quarantine), MECQ (Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine), GCQ (General Community Quarantine), MGCQ (Modified General Community Quarantine) continue to suspend face-to-face/in-person classes for basic education to April 30, 2021. Limited face-to-face/in-person classes are permitted for higher education and technical vocational education in areas under GCQ and MGCQ.    In addition, there remains a curfew in place until April 30: Any person below 18 and above 65 and those with health risks and pregnant women are required to remain at home shall be required to remain in their residences at all times, ""except for obtaining essential goods and services, or for work in industries and offices.""    ECQ: Puerto Princesa City – five barangays.  MECQ: Metro Manila, Rizal, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Santiago City, Quirino?Province, and Abra.  GCQ: Luzon?– The entire Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR), Cagayan, Isabela, and Nueva Vizcaya in Region II, Batangas, and Quezon Province; Visayas?–Tacloban City; and Mindanao – Davao City, Iligan City, and Lanao Del Sur.  MGCQ: All other areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419022719/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419215949/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210415-OMNIBUS-RRD.pdf

The Department [of Education] has adopted distance learning modalities and alternative work arrangements, which minimize the health and safety risks brought about not only by the pandemic, but also by typhoons, flooding, and other weather disturbances that learners and teachers might be exposed to. Localized cancellation/ suspension of classes and work due to natural and/or human-induced calamities, in both public and private schools,  regardless of learning delivery modality, and work in government offices shall be at the discretion of local chief executives.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426192937/https://www.deped.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/DO_s2021_014.pdf

Effective 29 March 2021 to 4 April 2021, the Philippine government has placed the provinces of Metro Manila, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal and the National Capital Region under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) as the strictest of lockdown measures. Effective April 1 until April 30, 2021, Santiago City is placed under Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ). Effective April 1 until April 15, 2021, Quirino Province is placed under MECQ. Effective until April 30, 2021 Luzon, the entire Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR); Cagayan, Isabela, and Nueva Vizcaya are placed under General Community Quarantine (MGCQ). All other areas are placed under Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ) until end of April 2021.   Exemptions of the ECQ include: Public and private hospitals; health emergency and frontline services; manufacturers of medical supplies; agricultural industries; logistics service providers; construction projects; hygiene products manufacturing; essential retail trade; food preparation establishments; public and private financial service providers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329202012/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/20210328-OMNIBUS-Guidelines-RRD.pdf

Announced April 4, as a continuation of the Enhanced Community Quarantine currently imposed on the provinces of Bulacan, Cavite, laguna, Rizal, and highly urbanized cities of the National Capital Region and Pateros municpality will be extended to April 11, 2021.  Non-essential workplaces are required to close with the exception of: Public and private hospitals; health emergency and frontline services; manufacturers of medical supplies; agricultural industries; logistics service providers; construction projects; hygiene products manufacturing; essential retail trade; food preparation establishments; public and private financial service providers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405230551/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210404-Resolution-108A-RRD.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329202012/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/20210328-OMNIBUS-Guidelines-RRD.pdf

The Enhanced Community Quarantine currently imposed on the provinces of Abra, Bulacan, Cavite, laguna, Rizal, and highly urbanized cities of the National Capital Region and Pateros municipality will continue from April 12 to April 30, 2021.  Non-essential workplaces are remain to close as directed by the April 4th Enhance Community Quarantine announcement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412031525/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210410-IATF-RESOLUTION-109-A.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405230551/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210404-Resolution-108A-RRD.pdf

Non-essential workplaces continue to be suspended for the duration of areas in ECQ until April 30.  Some non-essential workplaces are suspended in MECQ, GCQ, and MGCQ areas until April 30.    ECQ: Puerto Princesa City – five barangays.  MECQ: Metro Manila, Rizal, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Santiago City, Quirino?Province, and Abra.  GCQ: Luzon?– The entire Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR), Cagayan, Isabela, and Nueva Vizcaya in Region II, Batangas, and Quezon Province; Visayas?–Tacloban City; and Mindanao – Davao City, Iligan City, and Lanao Del Sur.  MGCQ: All other areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419022719/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419215949/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210415-OMNIBUS-RRD.pdf

Created sector category breakouts (1 - 3, other) with further restrictions of protected groups, listed at   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426191024if_/https://www.covid19.gov.ph/economic/establishments. Effective 29 March 2021 to 4 April 2021, the Philippine government has placed the provinces of Metro Manila, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, Rizal and the National Capital Region under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) as the strictest of lockdown measures. Effective April 1 until April 30, 2021, Santiago City is placed under Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ). Effective April 1 until April 15, 2021, Quirino Province is placed under MECQ. Effective until April 30, 2021 Luzon, the entire Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR); Cagayan, Isabela, and Nueva Vizcaya are placed under General Community Quarantine (MGCQ). All other areas are placed under Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ) until end of April 2021. Any person below 18 and above 65 and those with health risks and pregnant women are required to remain at home ‘except when indispensable circumstances for obtaining essential goods and services’.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329202012/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/20210328-OMNIBUS-Guidelines-RRD.pdf

Announced April 4, as a continuation of the Enhanced Community Quarantine currently imposed on the provinces of Bulacan, Cavite, laguna, Rizal, and highly urbanized cities of the National Capital Region and Pateros municpality will be extended to April 11, 2021.  Curfew continues to be in place for: Metro Manila, Cavite, Bulacan, Laguna, and Rizal remain under curfew from 6:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. until further notice. Any person below 18 and above 65 and those with health risks and pregnant women are required to remain at home ‘except when indispensable circumstances for obtaining essential goods and services’.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405161557/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405230551/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210404-Resolution-108A-RRD.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329202012/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/20210328-OMNIBUS-Guidelines-RRD.pdf

The Philippine government has suspended the entry of all foreign nationals through April 21, 2021. In addition, the number of inbound international passengers has been limited to 1,500 per day.  The following individuals are exempt from the entry ban provided they have a valid visa at the time of entry: Diplomats and members of international organizations, and their dependents; Foreign nationals involved in medical repatriation duly endorsed by Department of Foreign Affairs; Foreign seafarers under the “Green Lanes” program for crew change; Foreign parent/s, spouses and children of Filipino citizens traveling with the Filipino citizen; and Emergency, humanitarian, and other analogous cases approved by the Chairperson of the NTF COVID-19 or his duly authorized representative.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405161557/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Announced March 30, 22.9 million individuals or 80 percent of the low-income population in the National Capital Region, Bulacan, Cavite, Laguna, and Rizal or the so-called NCR plus bubble, will receive P1,000 amelioration assistance from the national government for the duration of the one-week Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ). As many as four individuals can receive the amelioration assistance per family.  The Palace spokesperson and concurrent Inter-Agency Task Force (IATF) spokesperson said that the possibility of extending the ECQ for another week is being carefully studied by the IATF.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405235030/https://pcoo.gov.ph/news_releases/ecq-affected-individuals-to-receive-amelioration-assistance-from-government-palace/

A, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Announced March 28, Philippine will begin vaccinating the elderly alongside healthcare workers. The country has so far received 525,600 doses of AstraZeneca vaccines through the World Health Organization-led COVAX Facility. Apart from AstraZeneca vaccines, the country has also so far got 1 million doses Sinovac’s CoronaVac vaccine donated by Chinese government.  The national government’s vaccine priority list are as follows: A1 refers to frontline medical workers, A2 refers to senior citizens aged 60 and above, and A3 refers to persons with comorbidities.    In addition, President Duterte has announced Philippine will allow private companies to import COVID-19 vaccines ""at will"" in order to vaccinate their workers, in addition to those secured by the government provided the orders follow guidelines and are approved by the National Task Force.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406003259/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135144  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329072412/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135197    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406003846/https://pcoo.gov.ph/news_releases/govt-allows-private-firms-to-import-covid-19-vaccines/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330095530/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135371

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): In press briefing with the Presidential Spokesperson of Philippine, ""as of April 3, 2021, 795,320 people have been vaccinated with the first dose of COVID-19 vaccines at 2,669 vaccination sites in the country. Of this number, 765,871 are frontline health care workers. Vaccination has also begun for senior citizens and individuals with comorbidities. A total of 16,121 grandparents were vaccinated in NCR and Region IV-A, while 13,328 were vaccinated against individuals with comorbidity.""    The Philippines aims to secure 148 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines from several companies to inoculate an initial 50 to 70 million Filipinos this year. The bulk of vaccine doses are expected to arrive by the second and third quarters of the year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406004822/https://pcoo.gov.ph/press-briefing/press-briefing-with-presidential-spokesperson-harry-roque-12/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406004846/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135813

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): The Department of Health (DOH) on April 8 adopted the recommendation of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to temporarily suspend the use of AstraZeneca vaccines for individuals aged below 60 years old, following reports of rare cases of blood clots with low platelets detected in some individuals inoculated with the vaccine.  To date, the National Adverse Events Following Immunization Committee has not received any local reports of such side effects.  The NTF and the DOH reiterated that vaccination is safe and free. Senior citizens and persons with comorbidities are urged to receive the available vaccines from their local government units.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412034914/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1136165

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Directed by the government of Philippines, local government units are further enjoined to prioritize the generation of the demand for vaccination to those with highest risk for severe disease and death, particularly Priority Groups A2 (senior citizens aged 60 and above) and A3 (persons with comorbidities).  Use of AstraZeneca on persons under 60 continues to be suspended.    500,000 more doses of Sinovac vaccines arrived on Sunday afternoon from Beijing.  Jabs from Russia's Gamaleya Research Institute and US firm Moderna will arrive this month while deals with Pfizer-Biotech are ongoing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412031525/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210410-IATF-RESOLUTION-109-A.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412035821/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1136401

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Priority Groups A1 (frontline medical workers), A2 (senior citizens aged 60 and above) and A3 (persons with comorbidities) continue to be prioritized for vaccinations.  When there is sufficient supply of vaccines, Priority Group A4 (essential workers) will be able to get vaccinated simultaneously with the previous 3 groups. A4 Essential workers include: members of the media, basic education personnel, government workers, and economic frontliners.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419233202/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1136850  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419233523/http://www.radyopilipinas.ph/rp-one/articles/national/a4-catergory-sa-pagbabakuna-posible-nang-simulan-sa-oras-na-madagdagan-ang-mga-bakuna-sa-bansa

Per Measure 9,    ""Venues or parts of venues must immediately close for the duration of the Pandemic that:  a. provide night club and pub activities and services;  b. provide gambling activities and services; or  c. sell and supply alcohol, takeaway alcohol or alcohol for consumption on the premises  without food, except restaurants.  . Venues or parts of venues that operate as a restaurant or for food consumption on premises may operate subject to;  a. all persons on entry and exist from venues must wash their hands with soap or hand sanitiser; and  b. follow all other hygiene standards as issued by the Controller.  No licensed premises shall sell takeaway alcohol, except restaurants, which may only sell alcohol for consumption on their premises.  The following operating hours shall apply:    a. Retail outlets and shops may only operate from 7am to 8pm""    See the NCC's Measures, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/xpqofo1aa2qcpj9/PNG-20210412-NCCMeasures.pdf

Restaurant owners must also submit seating area and compliance plans to provincial officials to maintain operations. All nightclubs, bars, and gambling establishments remain closed indefinitely; establishments that sell takeaway alcohol sales can only operate Monday-Friday. Domestic air travel is restricted to essential travel, enforced by air service providers, and also requires COVID-19 testing.    US Embassy Web Archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405005854/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Per Measure 11,    ""I, Commissioner David Manning, Controller, by virtue of the powers conferred by Section 9 of the National Pandemic Act 2020 and all other enabling powers, hereby issue the following measures:    25-30 seater public transport vehicles may continue to operate during if passenger numbers are limited to 15 passengers.  All other public transport vehicles, including vessels may continue to operate but only if passenger numbers are limited to 5 less than the vehicle licensed capacity.  Taxis may operate but only if passenger numbers are limited to 2.  All persons on public transport including the driver and passengers must at all times while on the public transportation wear a mask of face covering in compliance with the requirements in Measure 10.  Private transportation may continue to operate, including but not limited to hotel and security transportation.  An individual or organisation who fails to adhere to the Measure shall be deemed to have committed an offence under the National Pandemic Act 2020.""    See the NCC's Measures, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/xpqofo1aa2qcpj9/PNG-20210412-NCCMeasures.pdf

Officials will continue to limit capacity to 15 people on 25-30-seat public transport vehicles nationally. Other public transport, including vessels, can operate at five fewer passengers than capacity; taxis can only carry two customers. Officials have threatened to impound any vehicle that defies capacity limits, though compliance and enforcement have varied previously.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426181415/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/457436/papua-new-guinea-authorities-to-further-tighten-restrictions-nationwide-from-march-22-amid-rising-covid-19-activity-update-28

According to the US Embassy in PNG,    ""Movement Restrictions:        Is a curfew in place? An official national curfew not currently in place, but business operations are limited to prescribed hours. Note that curfews and other measures may be imposed by provincial government authorities.      Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes, interprovincial domestic air travel is restricted to persons working for approved organizations or persons who have approval from the Office of the Controller or the provincial administrator of the province from which the travel originates. Travelers should consult with their respective airline(s) prior to travel.      The Controller has also delegated authority to provincial governments to establish their own requirements for travel. All domestic air travelers are strongly encouraged to confirm requirements with their respective air service provider(s) prior to travel.""    See the US Embassy in PNG's website, archived at https://archive.vn/qBT0v

The government will restrict interprovincial travel, except for essential reasons or with official permission; travel between Central Province and the National Capital District (NCD) and Kerema Open Electorate, Gulf Province, may continue. Officials allow domestic flights for essential reasons, such as student or essential business travel, medical assistance or evacuation, or people returning to their usual residence. From March 22, authorities will require passengers to have a negative COVID-19 test result within 24 hours of departure; staffers will accept either an Antigen Rapid Diagnostic Test or reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Passengers must still undergo temperature checks before boarding and complete a National Department of Health form to submit to provincial authorities upon landing. Provincial officials can also request that arrivals take an RT-PCR COVID-19 test and quarantine people who refuse to test for up to 14 days at their own cost.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426181415/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/457436/papua-new-guinea-authorities-to-further-tighten-restrictions-nationwide-from-march-22-amid-rising-covid-19-activity-update-28
Quarantine and negative test required.     US Embassy Web Archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405005854/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As per the US Embassy in PNG's website, foreign travellers are allowed to come into PNG but only for very specific reasons, and are largely required to quarantine for 14 days at a government-approved facility.    ""      Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes. but please read this section carefully. Travelers are only allowed to enter with a valid visa and explicit written approval to enter from the National Pandemic Controller. Under measures instituted by the Controller, incoming travelers are only allowed to enter by air at Port Moresby International Airport. In general, travelers should not attempt to enter the country via its sea and land borders unless they have explicit approval to do so. Visas on arrival are NOT available at this time.      U.S. citizens who wish to enter the country must submit to the National Control Center (NCC) Travel Desk (covid19-travel@police.gov.pg) the following as early as possible.          Cover letter stating the reason for travel and any compelling circumstances, as well information on the planned itinerary. See a sample letter here.          Completed Air Passenger Travel Form, including date of travel to Papua New Guinea, selected quarantine hotel/location, and a copy of the traveler’s passport          Copy of the traveler’s passport biodata page          Copy of the traveler’s Papua New Guinean work permit (if applicable)          Copy of the traveler’s Papua New Guinean visa (if applicable)          Proof of 14 days quarantine at an approved facility (as listed in Schedule 4 of Measure 2 regarding international travel).""    ""Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? Yes. All incoming travelers are required to quarantine at an government-approved quarantine site. A full list of approved quarantine sites may be found in Measure 2 – International Travel Measures, which is available at the government’s COVID-19 Information Portal. Additionally, travelers who enter Papua New Guinea via Port Moresby and then travel to AROB and who have not adhered to requirements set forth by the Autonomous Bougainville Government may be required to undergo an additional 14 days quarantine in AROB.""    See US Embassy in PNG's webpage, archived at https://archive.vn/qBT0v

According to the US Embassy in PNG,    ""COVID-19 Testing:        Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Papua New Guinea? Yes      If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes, upon request and with additional fees for expedited processing.      Symptomatic persons are generally able to obtain free or government-subsidized testing services at Port Moresby General Hospital, the Taurama Aquatic Center, and other public clinics in Port Moresby. Testing services outside of Port Moresby may be obtained at provincial hospital or by calling 1800 200 and asking for more information.      Non-symptomatic persons and persons who need testing services in connection with travel may obtain such services through approved swabbing centers and private medical facilities, including:          2K Medical Clinic          Pacific International Hospital          Aspen Medical          Sky Medical Services        Testing conducted through private medical facilities for the purpose of travel may cost as much as 250 USD.""    See the US Embassy in PNG's website, archived at https://archive.vn/qBT0v

Symptomatic persons are generally able to obtain government-paid or government-subsidized testing services at the National Referral Hospital in Honiara. Symptomatic persons should contact the Public Health Emergency Surveillance Unit at +677 23650 or +677 752 2202 for further instructions.  Non-symptomatic persons and persons who need testing services in connection with travel may obtain such services by following the instructions below as early as possible:  Write to Permanent Secretary Pauline McNeil (PMcneil@moh.gov.sb) and Incident Controller Dr. Gregory Jilini (GJilini@moh.cov.sb) to request pre-departure testing and include 1). the entry requirements for the destination country or countries, 2). the number of tests required and, if applicable, how many days apart, and 3) whether a COVID-19 certificate is also required.  In addition to the email, hand deliver the letter/request above to the National Health Emergency Operations Center at the Ministry of Health in Chinatown.  Once testing services are approved, the National Health Emergency Operations Center will confirm with the traveler a time and place for swabbing/sampling.  Testing services may cost as much as 190 USD.  Though physical or electronic test results are generally available within 24-48 hours, depending on the type of test conducted, U.S. citizens who need tests in connection with travel are advised to request clear estimates of the turn-around and delivery methods for test results.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to CDC’s requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID test, Humanitarian exemptions to this order will be granted on an extremely limited basis and will only be considered when the country of departure lacks adequate COVID testing capacity  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426183624/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Per Measure No 10 of the National Pandemic Act,    ""I, Commissioner David Manning, Controller, by virtue of the powers conferred by Section 9 of the National Pandemic Act 2020 and all other enabling powers, hereby issue the following  measures:  1. All persons should where possible where masks to protect Papua New Guinea from COVID-19.  2. No person shall be permitted entry into, or otherwise remain within, any market designated in Schedule 1 unless the person is wearing a Mask or Face Covering, in a manner which covers their mouth, nose and chin.  3. No person shall be permitted entry to, or otherwise remain within, any enclosed space within an Establishment unless the person is wearing a Mask or Face Covering, in a manner which covers their mouth, nose and chin.  4. No person shall be permitted entry into or otherwise remain on, public transport unless the person is wearing a Mask or Face Covering, in a manner which covers their mouth, nose and chin.  5. No person shall be permitted entry into an aircraft anywhere in PNG unless the person is wearing a Mask or Face Covering in a manner which covers their mouth, nose and chin.  6. No person shall remove their Mask or Face Covering whilst on an aircraft in PNG in a manner which covers their mouth, nose and chin, except in the case of an emergency.  7. The pilots of the plane are exempt from paragraphs 5 and 6.  8. All persons working in a market, in-door establishment or on public transport in which they interact in person with customers, clients or work in an enclosed space with other colleagues must wear masks at all times.  9. Businesses and government departments and agencies must ensure all employees have Masks or Face Coverings""    See the NCC's Measures, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/xpqofo1aa2qcpj9/PNG-20210412-NCCMeasures.pdf

Authorities also now require businesses and public transport operators to deny entry to people without face coverings. All companies with indoor operations must provide workers with face coverings and ensure their use. The government mandates face coverings at most indoor locations, including offices and government agencies, public transport, and airplanes. Exceptions are in place for childcare centers, banks, children under 12 years old, or while eating.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426181415/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/457436/papua-new-guinea-authorities-to-further-tighten-restrictions-nationwide-from-march-22-amid-rising-covid-19-activity-update-28

A- Key Worker    Australia sent Papua New Guinea 8,000 doses of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine last week after warning of a worsening humanitarian crisis. It has sent almost 8,500 vaccine doses to immunize frontline workers in its former colony and is considering distributing more once it begins to ramp up local production of the AstraZeneca shot.    Nikkei Asia Web Archived: web.archive.org/web/20210405011612/https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Coronavirus/Australia-vaccine-diplomacy-tested-as-COVID-slams-Papua-New-Guinea

A:    Vaccine used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19)    As previously reported, PNG started vaccinations on 30th March 2021, with Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines provided by the Australian Government. Additionally, on 13th April 2021, the PNG government has reported that its first batch of vaccines (also the Oxofrd-AstraZeneca type) procured through the COVAX facility, amounting to 132k doses, have arrived in Port Moresby, and ""[this] vaccine will be distributed to all provinces for the vaccination of health care workers and other front line essential workers.""    See the PNG government's reports, archived at https://archive.vn/vVzQE and https://archive.vn/lceFm

The COVAX shipment of the AstraZeneca vaccine arrived in PNG on 13 April 2021. A total of 132,000 doses were received and will be allocated to health care workers and other front line essential staff  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426185507/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/Situation%20Report/PNG%20COVID-19%20Health%20Situation%20Report%2069%20FINAL.pdf

The code of 1G continues to be valid and signifies that the educational arrangements are significantly different to the situation prior to the Covid-19 pandemic.  The ""safe management measures"" from the Ministry of Education FAQ page are detailed below:    ""With school reopening in 2021, what are the safe management measures put in place in schools?""    ""Safe management measures in schools will continue to include the following:    Screening    Twice-daily temperature-taking and visual screening for all students and staff.  Students and staff who are unwell, or who have household members on Home Quarantine Order/Stay Home Notice or have adult household members with flu-like symptoms such as fever and cough, are required to stay away from school.  It is not mandatory for students to have their TraceTogether tokens when school reopens. The tokens will only be required in schools after nationwide distribution is completed.    Hygiene    Frequent cleaning of high-touch surfaces and disinfection of the premises to be done daily.  Students will continue to practise frequent hand-washing throughout the school day and wipe down of tables and shared equipment after use.    Safe Distancing    Fixed group seating of up to eight from the same class will be allowed.  CCAs and external learning journeys of up to 50 people conducted in a fixed group with exclusive use of venues (if possible) are allowed.  Curricular, co-curricular and enrichment activities with fixed intermingling across schools are allowed.  Staggered arrival, dismissal and recess timings to reduce congestion.""        Will all CCAs and school activities be resumed? [UPDATED, 18 Feb, 6:45pm]  Most CCAs and school activities are allowed to resume while activities that involve the following will remain suspended:    Trips to view external performances due to higher risk of intermingling with other schools and the public;  Activities with high level of body contact such as Taekwondo sparring, Rugby scrum and tackle;  Overnight camps.  Schools will continue to safeguard our students' well-being during CCAs and school activities, by implementing the necessary safe management measures (SMMs). This includes minimising prolonged inter-mingling between students and members of the public for activities held at external venues, such as Learning Journeys.    From SG Ministry of Education FAQs.  (Cannot be archived as the page consists of drop down items.  The page link is here:  https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection).

Schools in Singapore continue functioning in Phase 3 as they have been in Phase 2 despite the emergence of new variants in the community.  In-person lessons have long resumed, but remain significantly different to pre-pandemic times. Safe management measures are in place throughout the country and are as below (from the Ministry of Education - MOE).  ______________  Quote (1):  ""Yes, all centre-based lessons# will continue as in Phase 2 with the safe management measures that are in place. In addition, measures such as fixed seating arrangements, class groupings, staggered dismissal time and recess are put in place to mitigate the risk of intermingling among students from different schools.""    ""With school reopening in 2021, what are the safe management measures put in place in schools?  Safe management measures in schools will continue to include the following:    Screening    Twice-daily temperature-taking and visual screening for all students and staff.  Students and staff who are unwell, or who have household members on Home Quarantine Order/Stay Home Notice or have adult household members with flu-like symptoms such as fever and cough, are required to stay away from school.
